campaign.story:
Five years ago, CONAN the board game became a massive hit and spawned a faithful community of players, designers, and enthusiasts. Brand new content has been long in coming, but it’s finally time to unlock the remaining quantities of 1st Edition boxes alongside the release of our biggest Hyborian Age expansion ever.
Those who wish to wet their swords for the first time and veterans from previous campaigns shall join ranks and heed the call of Conan the Conqueror!
Not only is the Adventure Mode (our original one vs many system) gameplay you know and love making its return, but we’re also adding a revised version of the solo/co-op rules featured in the Conan Monolith Sourcebook. Regardless of which version of Conan you own, or plan to purchase, all of the new content will pair perfectly with what you have.
To celebrate its 5th Anniversary, we are making the Conan: The Boardgame, the 2015 classic 1st Edition available again in limited quantities. Combined with the new mega-Conqueror expansion you’ll be able to enter the savage worlds and raise your own bloodied sword. 
This new expansion will boost options for ALL owners of the Conan Board Game. To play all of these new scenarios, you require only the core version of the game; however, King Pledge and Barbarian Pledge owners will find further options in some of the included scenarios.
All of these scenarios will be presented in the Tome of Skelos: a 60+ page hardcover book in the style of our previous titles. Inside, you will find 6 brand new scenarios for the original Conan Adventure mode (one vs many mode) that make use of all the new miniatures, maps and tiles. We will add a seventh scenario if its Stretch Goal is unlocked.
We’ve also included an updated version of the solo/co-op rules that debuted in the Conan Monolith Sourcebook as well as a campaign of 7 specially designed solo co-op scenarios, where players will choose their heroes, gather equipment, and gain powerful Boons to complete their escape across the Pictish Wilderness. The Version 1 rules can be found below as well as a description of the gameplay. The Tome will also feature brand new artwork created for this campaign.
If you are using Internet Explorer or Safari and you can not see the following animated images, please click here. 
Solo/cooperative rules allow players to play through specially designed scenarios that eliminate the role of the Overlord. Instead, the players themselves will control the Overlord’s tiles and miniatures.
Click the download link below for a look at these rules. Note these are the V1 rules and are provided courtesy of Modiphius. Our rules will be laid out in our own style and there will be minor updates to the system. These changes, as well as a closer look at the solo/co-op system, will be explained in a forthcoming KS update. 

The pirates of the Red Brotherhood have spread out from the Baracha Isles and haunt every shore of the Western Sea. It is said they have even raised sail on the inland waters of the Vilayet. This organization, composed mainly of Argosseans, maintains a notorious rivalry with the Zingaran Freebooters, and their bloody feuds have turned the tides a deeper shade of crimson. 
These are tales of high seas and high adventure. These are the tales of the Red Brotherhood.
Fred Henry is returning to the design table and cooking up four new Adventure Mode scenarios. These exciting adventures make use of the brand new double-sided pirate ship game boards and only require the core/retail version of Conan AND the all-new contents featured in the Conan the Conqueror expansion.
If you are using Internet Explorer or Safari and you can not see the following animated image, please click here.
 A Hero steps from the mists of time to aid King Conan against an invisible threat. But behind this man stalks a threat older than the Earth itself.
If you are using Internet Explorer or Safari and you can not see the following animated images, please click here.

The Hidden chambers expansion offers 4 mini maps that represent secret rooms. Once you find the door and pick its lock, you may enter the gloomy depths to find treasures, special items, or—perhaps—death. These Chamber Boards are set alongside the main game board, denoting a separate floor or level rather than altering an existing room. 
Depths of the Lost Citadel
As well as offering brand new options for scenario designers, The Hidden Chambers Map Expansion also comes with its own special solo/co-op scenario AND an Adventure Mode scenario for the new Citadel map—“In the Depths of the Lost Citadel”. These scenarios require the core/retail version of Conan (or King or Barbarian pledge) and the new Conqueror expansion.
Players will assume the roles of hired swords with a mission: enter the lost citadel of an ancient sorcerer and steal a fabled artefact. To manage this dangerous feat, they must avoid traps, uncover secret doors, and battle the unspeakable horrors lurking beneath. And even if they manage all this, it is unlikely the sorcerer will let them leave with their lives.
For solo/co-op mode, this expansion will allow players to add an optional scenario to the campaign offered in the Tome of Skelos.
During the feasting of swords, it's not always convenient to pass the dice to your friend, or  even worse--your enemy! Many have asked, so we're offering a comfort dice pack as an add-on. Happy slaying!

Conan is a miniature-based board game that pits 1 to 4 players representing Conan and his fellow rogues against another more nefarious player—the Overlord. Like any good villain, the Overlord controls hordes of savage tribesmen, beasts, and soldiers from an age undreamed of.
The gameplay is asymmetrical. The Overlord commands a massive horde of monsters and villains, as he strives to meet his objectives. On the other side are the heroes, each controlled by a player in a more first-person fashion, giving the game an RPG feel.
Each scenario can be played out in approximately one hour and takes place on one of several beautiful game boards. Regardless of which role you play, you must stake your wits, mettle and martial prowess against your opponent.

The new Adventure Mode scenarios featured in the Conan the Conqueror expansion are inspired by Robert E. Howard’s only Conan novel—The Hour of the Dragon—as well as other Howard classics and the wild speculations of our lotus-maddened designers. In any case, the flavor of high adventure will be stinging like wine on your palate!
 Three years ago, based on popular demand, Matt John wrote a brand new mode for the Conan Monolith Sourcebook based on the existing Conan board game system, where the Overlord’s role is dictated by these new rules and the special rules of a given scenario (Note that Solo/Co-op scenarios are ONLY playable using the Solo/Coop rules; Adventure Mode scenarios CANNOT be played with the Solo/Coop rules). 
In this mode, the Hero gameplay remains the same, but the Overlord is given commands based on activation tokens and the special rules of the scenario. Some scenarios even flip the script entirely, presenting their own unique mini games. Overall, the gameplay is at once familiar and different, but nonetheless challenging.
Best enjoyed as a campaign, all of these brand new scenarios see players choosing Heroes,  collecting gear, spells, and even improving their characters with ‘Boons’.
As the story goes, your captain has lost his mind and your ship has burned down to a blackened husk. Your only hope at survival is to travel east from the coast and into the depths of the Pictish Wilderness. And that’s not much of a hope at all, now, is it? Will you face the green hell alone, or bring up to three friends along with you?
It’s time to join the thriving player community centered around the Overlord forums for an ever-expanding library of content: 100’s of scenarios, painting articles, gaming aids – a vast collection of fun and adventure for this popular board game.

campaign.story:
Let's start with this: Kickstarter employees have been working for months to get their union recognized, and faced a lot of pushback from senior Kickstarter leadership. Recently they were able to hold a vote to decide on the formation of this union, and while we will not know the results of that vote for some time, I still stand in support of those workers and recognizing KSRU. 
In compliance with the discussions they've been having with senior leadership their social media has gone dark, but you can still find out more at their website.
Hi! I'm Kales! I write games under the name A. Fell, and I publish them as Paradoxical Press! This game is built on the back of a story I have been telling, over and over again, with two dear friends of mine over the last two years. It's truly the result of a labor of love, and I'm so excited to turn it into something real and tangible you can hold in your hands and share with your friends, much like the tokens in the game proper.
Memoria is a game telling sprawling character histories over long periods of time. Inspired by such games as Microscope by Ben Robbins and Mobile Frame Zero: Firebrands by D. Vincent Baker, it tells the kinds of stories I like to tell best-- jumping around through time, dealing with the ever evolving relationships between characters and only as much politics as you want to exist, with a very freeform structure to scenes themselves. It is a game that explicitly and deliberately refuses to engage with major character death as a source of angst within the story itself. Yes, the game can take place over centuries; no, you don't have to explain how if you don't want to. The point is the characters.
The intro to gameplay, featuring one of the art pieces done by Serj.
The game uses small remnants of memory at its foundation-- tokens and echoes. Tokens are tangible-- gifts, letters, random knick-knacks, even scars and tattoos. Echoes are less tangible, more sense memory than anything else, but they carry the same weight. You call tokens and echoes in scenes shared with other characters as well as solitary moments you narrate alone. You can move in and out of scenes as your  characters or as the rest of the world, building an epic history of friends to enemies back to friends to lovers-- just as an example-- as the world shifts and pivots around you.
Currently, you can find Memoria on Itch as a digital-only download; however for the purposes of Zinequest I'll be offering the PDF only at half its usual price and producing a 5.5x8.5 (roughly A5 size) zine so you, too, can hold this game in your hands! They'll be printed and bound by me (time to flex the bookbinding skills I learned working in the library in college) and should hopefully be shipped by June, if not earlier.
The zine features beautifully done art by Lu which will span the entire front and back cover, inset pieces by Serj, and a gorgeous piece of art by Sam (which you can see a snippet of in the header for this project.) 
At the $15 tier, you can get the zine as well as a PDF of the game, which will have the new cover art and some interior layout tweaks. (If you already own the PDF, never fear-- the updated PDF will become available on the Itch page when the updated PDF goes out to backers, and you can always get the physical version only for $12.)
For $20, you can donate a physical copy to someone who might not be able to afford it. (Those will be available on a first-come first-serve basis, and will cost nothing on your end.) For every additional $10 over the base tier you pledge I'll add another physical copy to the pool (so a $40 pledge will donate three copies).
If you're international and outside one of the countries listed, message me! I will work something out with you as much as I can.
The budget may look a little small, but that's because I laid out the game myself and made some art happen already. Here is a breakdown of where the money is going:
 $100 for the new cover art, done by the lovely Lu, and other small pieces of art, including the header image which was done by Sam! 
 $50 for the art in the game already, done by Sam and Serj, as royalties for the work they did to help make this book beautiful.
 $150 for the printing, binding, and shipping, which I will be doing all myself (not using a third-party printer or fulfillment service).
 $50 compensation for myself.
 $50 for Kickstarter fees.
and $50 as a buffer.
We're fully funded! That's incredible! Let's talk about stretch goals!
You might be saying to yourself: Memoria exists as a game already! What more could we want! If you were following me during the several months or so I was writing this  game, you'll remember I was talking about a supplemental, featuring scene frameworks and potential dynamic seeds to serve as a jumping off point for players. One of those scene frameworks made it to Itch (a dance, a duel, which you can download right now for PWYW.) 
I've always been planning on writing it, but it would be really, really neat to be able to print it as well. If we can reach $800 I'll release the supplemental, containing Firebrands-style scene frameworks, character dynamic seeds, and an additional variant (or perhaps two) as a PDF bonus to all backers. That money will go towards paying for the writing and layout of the supplemental, which I estimate will be at least another eight to ten pages of content.
But you all are here for physical zines. So here's my promise. If we can reach $1000, I'll be able to print and bind the supplemental for all physical backers. It's a bit of a hefty goal, but it'll cover the costs of printing and shipping the additional weight.
If the project funds but a stretch goal is not reached, any extra funds will go towards the following things:
Paying my artists more for the work they've done.
My day-to-day work for bringing the game to you in its best state possible.

Risks and challenges
The game is already fully written, apart from the supplemental, so the real risk here is with fulfillment being done on time. For the sake of transparency, I have projected fulfillment to be complete by June since I am planning to move states in April, and that will suck up a lot of the time I could be spending binding zines. I know myself well and I know I will want to get a head start on fulfillment sooner, but I have given myself wiggle room in case of unforeseen circumstances.

I want to start by bringing attention to Kickstarter United, a collective of Kickstarter workers who have come together to create a union in their workplace. A vote was recently held to determine whether or not they will be successful, and during this process they are staying off social media, but I would urge you to stay informed by checking out their website and to be prepared to take action if they call for it in the future. 
This zine is made up of three different games. They're all based off the same single-player system, which uses a deck of cards and a six-sided die to generate prompts for the player to expand on. 
cover art from Alone Among the Stars
Alone Among the Stars is a solo adventuring game about exploring strange and fantastic planets and experiencing wondrous sights. I wrote it in the summer of 2018 while I was playing a lot of No Man's Sky really late at night. If you'd like to check it out before backing the zine, it's available for PWYW on my Itch.io page here. 
page 1 of my example playthrough of Alone Among the Stars
cover art from Alone in the Ancient City
Alone in the Ancient City was the first hack of AAtS that I wrote. It's about wandering through an old city with new eyes, and was inspired by trips to cities such as Venice and Montreal. If you'd like to check it out before backing this zine you can find the plaintext version on my Itch.io page here. 
Alone Among the Twisting Trees is a new game I'm writing for inclusion in this zine! It's about getting lost in a mysterious forest and the strange artifacts that you find inside. It was originally conceived through playstorming with Quinn Vega and Avi Margolis as an adaptation of another game I wrote, Alone on the Rocky Beach (not included in this zine).
In addition to these games, there are a ton of other hacks that have been inspired by Alone Among the Stars. If this zine doesn't stick out to you but you're still looking for a cool single-player experience, I'd recommend checking out the rest of these hacks! I've tried to compile all of them in this Itch collection, Alone at the Table. 
I think anyone can make a game, and hacking is a great way to get started. A number of the hacks in the Alone at the Table collection were made by first-time designers, and in order to make hacking the game even easier I'm including a template that you can fill in to make your own hack in the back of the zine, as well as a page or two of useful design tips to get you started. You could even use the journaling pages to start playtesting!
"In Alone in the Ancient City, designer Takuma Okada translates the melancholy, No Man’s Sky-esque galaxy-wide wandering of Alone Among the Stars into a more humble joy, one of discovering a city on your own. Ancient City captures the feeling of traveling through a place with a history and weight belonging to others, but wholly unfamiliar to you. Okada eschews the oft-trod territory of metropolitan tourism and spectacle in the pursuit of a more intimate exploration. This game is Urban Pastel at its finest." - Caro Asercion, designer of i'm sorry did you say street magic 
"Are you playing Alone Among the Stars? And following the Twitter account? Get on it. @among_stars_" - John Harper, designer of Blades in the Dark
Alone On A Journey: a collection of solo adventuring games is a 28 page zine featuring this amazing cover art by Shannon Kao. It will include these three Alone games in a new layout by Quinn, a blank template of an Alone game with some pointers so you can make your own hack, and blank journaling pages in the back of the book so you can start writing right away. 
the cover for the zine!
 The zine is 5.5"x8.5" and will be printed through Mixam. The cover will be color on 110 lb. paper with a matte finish, and the inside pages will be black and white on 80 lb paper. 
In the spirit of Zinequest, I've tried to keep the budget low while paying collaborators fairly. The total comes out to $500 given a 50 print run. 
$225 for printing, shipping, and fulfillment: This should cover a 50 zine print run and shipping related costs for a mix of US and International orders. 
$75 for the cover art by Shannon: The art is already paid for and completed, but this covers the amount that I paid out of pocket for it already.
$150 for layout by Quinn: This is a tentative layout budget for about 20 pages, some blank journaling pages, and a cover.
$50 for fees: This is to cover Kickstarter fees!
As you may have noticed, I haven't really budgeted for paying myself. This is partially because I've already made some money off these games selling them on Itch.io, but it's also because I really want this project to fund and put it out in the world. If it funds over the goal, the first thing I'll be doing is paying myself and upping the print run to 100 copies. Beyond that I've been throwing around some ideas for stretch goals but haven't settled on anything yet, and I don't really want to assume a huge overshoot given the nature of Zinequest. If it looks like we will though, I may announce some extra goals on this page. 
Hi! My name's Takuma Okada, and I'm a Japanese American writer, musician, and game designer. I started making games almost two years ago now, and I'm really excited to finally have the chance to make one of my first games into a physical zine! Some of my other games include Stewpot: Tales From a Fantasy Tavern, Chess: Two Kingdoms, and Etude of the Evening. I love beautiful places and strange objects and try to make them easy to find in my games.
Quinn Vega is a queer game designer, graphic designer, and musician based out of Portland, OR. Her games include For The Honor, Lightning Kissed, and cowriting Songs for the Dusk with Kavita Poduri. When she is not making or playing games she works making microphones and leading her band, The Variants. You can find her on twitter @Mx_quinn and her work at mxquinn.itch.io.
Shannon Kao is an artist from Seattle who works in comics and illustration. She's interested in stories about how places—real & imagined—shape the people in them. You can find more of her work on her website!

campaign.story:
This project recognises and supports Kickstarter United.
Nature’s rule is absolute. Her arbiters are the butchers, roving adventurers who seek out imbalances in the natural order and help restore harmony. Caught between the human world and the spiritual realm of Nature herself, butchers are tasked with investigating supernatural phenomena, rooting out the cause, and taking it to the sword.
Because in this world, there are monsters. Born of humanity’s meddling and misdeeds, these unnatural creatures represent the worst of us.
Can people ever exist as part of the natural world? Or is our very presence upsetting the balance?
Find out by slaying some of humanity’s literal demons.
BUTCHERY is a set of rules and tools for tabletop roleplaying in a liquorice fantasy setting inspired by the monster-hunting intrigue and action of The Witcher and Monster Hunter, the twisted fairytales of Angela Carter and the ecological storytelling of Hayao Miyazaki.
Liquorice fantasy? That’s my term for dark fantasy that’s not dark and bitter for its own sake, but rather in service of an overall sweetness. Less grimdark, more Grimm.
And who are you? Hi! I’m D G Chapman (he/they), writer and game designer. I’ve written official modules for the Mothership RPG, and designed games for the Wish You Were Here zine by World Champ Game Co. during last year’s ZineQuest. I’ve also done some of my own stuff, like the game-neutral low magic system Bastard Magic. Oh and one time I made a game about golf.
BUTCHERY is the ruleset I use in my home game :)
Ok, so what are BUTCHERY’s mechanics like? Rules light, rules tight. Inspired by the post-OSR movement (“artpunk”? “SWORDDREAM”? whatever we’re calling ourselves these days), BUTCHERY provides a simple framework and implied setting to let your group’s roleplaying take centre stage. Make characters in a minute and get playing right away.
Anything else? Yeah! There’s a slimline tactical combat system that provides the climactic setpiece battles modern players are used to seeing in actual play shows, without all the mechanical gubbins. Resolve attacks, hit locations, damage and monster reactions all in a single roll, scaling instantly to any group size.
Combats in BUTCHERY are investigative mini games – learn about your prey during and before the fight, and find the best way to take it down!
What’s in the zine?
-  Rules and tools for running your game and creating characters.
-  A no-prep-necessary adventure to introduce your group to your game.
-  Play examples and developer commentary throughout to help you hack this thing to pieces.
-  Amazing art! We’ve already got Bastard Magic artist Eleanor Bergmann signed on to the project, and would love to get some other guest artists in too.
art from Bastard Magic
Wot, no physical version? Digital distribution saves me and you time and money, cuts out the logistical nightmare of printing and shipping, helps the environment kinda, and lets a small team who’re doing all this themselves get your game done on time. You can always print your own copy if you’d like!
…But if it’s not printed, is it even a zine? Big shrug.
When and how do I get the zine? Text is done, barring further playtest tweaks and final editing. Once we’ve got the art in (using the proceeds from this KS project), we’ll go into layout. The final product will be delivered as a digital download some time before the end of 2020 (a conservative estimate to allow us a little extra wiggle room if needed! It’ll likely be done much sooner).

campaign.story:
The conclusion is already in place: You have failed. The Queen is dead.
Our Queen Crumbles is a collaborative storytelling game for 2-4 players about revenge, inevitable death, and saying goodbye to those you love. It is set in the weird-fantasy land of Halloway, where the dead whisper to those who listen and the fundamental forces of nature can be bent to your will. The game is meant to be played in a single sitting, and is focused on developing interesting and dynamic characters over the course of a few hours—no matter your roleplaying experience.
You will take on the role of The Knight of Whispers, The Gravity Witch, The Hangman Golem, and The Bloody Historian, the four most loyal retainers of a once great Queen. Go on an epic fantasy road trip as you pursue the Queen’s killer to the Tree Under the Mountain, and use what time you have left to say farewell.
The Gravity Witch
The Queen of Halloway was once revered and feared in equal measure. She ruled over a vast and wild land at the edge of the world, home to human, fey, and magickal creature alike. The land itself defied all taming—deserts bloomed with crystalline roses, boiling rivers ran through the forests, and towering prisms gathered on the plains like the eggs of some great beast—yet still the people of Halloway made their own place there.
On the far coast, the Lonely City presided over the Queendom. It was here that the Queen held court, brokering peace and passing judgement as she saw fit. She felt safe behind impenetrable stone walls, guarded by her army of living statues. 
Then the Assassin came, and the Queen's peace was shattered. By the time the Queen's retainers arrived, she lay dead in a crimson pool at the foot of her throne.
The Queen's closest friend, the Gravity Witch, moved first. She gathered from the throne room a pile of broken statue shards. With quick motions and practiced sounds she spun the fundamental forces around her will, and formed from the shattered stone an amalgam body from the disparate parts. And with a groan, she threw gravity into chaos, and drew the soul of the dead Queen back from wherever it meant to go—into the amalgam body.
Yet this is only a temporary solution. The reforged statue is not fit to hold a human soul for long. She will soon crumble.
There is, therefore, only one thing remaining to the Queen: Revenge.
The Hangman Golem
Our Queen Crumbles uses a new GM-less storytelling system centered on progressive character revelation—though you start the game with only a vague idea of who your characters are, each scene lets you dive into their history and personality a bit more. Players build scenes around a collection of character traits and story elements, allowing you to do on-the-fly worldbuilding alongside your friends.
Each player will choose a playbook from the available character archetypes, The Knight of Whispers, The Gravity Witch, The Hangman Golem, and The Bloody Historian. The players will also share two table playbooks, The Queen, and The Assassin. Playbooks contain an assortment of character traits, items, and abilities for the players to choose from as they travel on their journey. Instead of character advancement that makes you more powerful, Our Queen Crumbles features character advancement that makes you more interesting—every box you mark on your sheet drives the story forward, giving you a better picture of the character you play.
Character Sheet Mockup
Who is the Little Stone God? Why does the Knight of Whispers carry the Salt and Iron crowns? What is the Tree Under the Mountain? Only you can decide.
The game trusts players to come up with conflict, intrigue, and answers to the questions they have.
Our Queen Crumbles is a supremely hackable system, and I already have plans for additions to the zine. Backers who support the game at the Gilded Vessel tier will get to come up with their own character archetypes, which I will turn into additional character sheets. These sheets will be collected and released to all backers as the Our Queen Crumbles: Retainers expansion.
The zine will be a 24-page printed booklet with a beautiful two-color cover illustrated and designed by Lonely Egg Studio. Internal illustrations by Al Lukehart will show off the fantastical setting throughout the text. The zine will contain everything you need to play a game of Our Queen Crumbles in a single sitting, including character sheets for each of the 4 playable characters, rules for setting scenes along your journey, and a map of Halloway depicting the path from the Lonely City to the Tree Under the Mountain.
Zine Mockup
 Crumbling Vessel ($5) - The complete digital collection of Our Queen Crumbles. This tier will get you everything you need to play the game, along with the Retainers expansion.
 Cracked Vessel ($10) - The physical version of Our Queen Crumbles. This tier will get you the beautiful zine, as well as the complete digital collection.
 Pristine Vessel ($20) - The signed physical version of Our Queen Crumbles, plus some extra physical goodies. This tier will get you the zine, pre-printed character sheets for your first game, and a stack of my postcard-sized hack of Our Queen Crumbles, The Golems of Claypit.
 Gilded Vessel ($60) - The storyteller's version of Our Queen Crumbles. Along with all the physical and digital rewards, I will create a custom character sheet for an archetype chosen by you. These character sheets will be compiled into Our Queen Crumbles' first expansion, Retainers, and you will be credited as the creator of your character.
Our Queen Crumbles was originally written in June of 2019 for the annual Game Chef RPG competition, and was one of the five English-language finalists.  I received some really encouraging feedback during the jam, and decided to refine the game and bring it to print as my first fully produced RPG.
In October 2019, I co-wrote a party-game hack of Our Queen Crumbles with Adam Vass, which we called The Golems of Claypit. The "Golem Game", as it came to be known, was a hit at Big Bad Con 2019 in Walnut Creek, CA. I got to play the game with a lot of my favorite RPG designers, and I was convinced that the system of character development was really fun to engage with.
By early January I had assembled a crack team of creatives to make this zine a reality, including Adam, Al Lukehart, Jessica Fong, and Sal V Cloak. Budgets were drafted, art was drawn, and marketing was dumped everywhere I could find.
The next chapter of this game's history is up to you.
The Bloody Historian
Jason Brown (he/him) is the lead designer for Our Queen Crumbles, and is solely to blame for the strange things hidden inside this zine. Beside writing games, Jason writes about games as the Indie RPG journalist for the Ennie-nominated blog Cannibal Halfling Gaming. Follow his game design and journalism here.
Adam Vass (he/him) is the production consultant and graphic designer for Our Queen Crumbles, as well as the co-designer of The Golems of Claypit. He has created many small-press RPG's as World Champ Game Co, including last year's amazing Zinequest project: Tome & Wish You Were Here. He is also currently running his own Kickstarter for Cobwebs, a neo-noir RPG.  Follow him here.
Al Lukehart (they/them) is the lead illustrator for Our Queen Crumbles. They have done art for such illustrious RPG's as: Ben Robbins' Follow, Justin Ford's Saviors of Hogtown, and Eli Kurtz's Errant Deeds: Tall Tales in the Blackwood. They are also getting ready to release a serial webcomic, PARSLEY, later this year. Check out their work here.
Lonely Egg Studio is the cover illustrator and designer for Our Queen Crumbles. Jessica Fong is the illustrator responsible for the amazing cover art, and Sal V Cloak was in charge of the graphic design and textual elements. They are also in the process of developing a surreal adventure video game called In the Keeper's Shadow, as well as running their own Zinequest Kickstarter for Invoccultas.
The Our Queen Crumbles team stands with Kickstarter United OPEIU 153.

Risks and challenges
The biggest risks to Our Queen Crumbles are delays associated with my lack of experience publishing physical versions of my games—namely printing and shipping. To keep this process smooth, I've hired Adam Vass of World Champ Game Co as a consultant for the campaign. He has a ton of experience fulfilling RPG projects, including multiple Kickstarter campaigns last year.

The game text itself is already written and just requires a bit of updating and polish. Most of the post-Kickstarter work is going to be art, layout, printing, and shipping—all of which I am confident I will be able to get done without major issues.

campaign.story:
DELVE: A Solo Game Of Digging Too Deep is a solo map drawing game that puts you in control of a dwarven hold as you discover the horrors that lurk below. This roughly 32 page A5 zine has everything you need to generate natural formations, forgotten ruins, enemies, wyrd magics, and ancient monstrosities. It has a simple turn-based combat system, rules for building your hold, and tips on how to implement your hold into your RPG world.
Inspired by games like Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Keeper, DELVE aims to capture that feeling of building and protecting a fortress in an unforgiving subterranean world.
All you need to play is, a pencil, paper (preferably 1" grid), and a deck of playing cards. 
The Under-King has put out a bounty to all the holds demanding a Void Crystal, a rare and powerful gem found only in the deepest caverns. 
Each round your dwarves will mine another square of the grid, you draw a card from your deck of playing cards and see what they found. Hearts ♥ and Diamonds ♦ are resources and trade goods that you'll use for building and hiring units while Clubs ♣ and Spades ♠ are natural formations and forgotten ruins. From ancient libraries to goblin lairs, these subterranean locales will become part of your hold's unique layout and may provide unexpected benefits. Or you might just unleash a horde of ravenous insects in which case, you'll need to fight.
Combat in DELVE is designed to allow for forward planning and strategic thinking without weighing you down with book-keeping. Essentially, all enemies follow the same goal of trying to reach the surface by killing their way through your hold. They can move one grid space per turn, as can all of your units. Once they get into combat, check the rock-paper-scissors style chart to see which group has the advantage and reduce each side by the STR of the other. 
Once combat is over, it's time to build! As long as a room has access to the hold via a mineshaft or another room, it's good to go. Just pay the cost, and draw it in an available grid (empty or repurpose an old ♣ or ♠ grid space). At this stage, you'll also have the opportunity to build traps, reinforce, and hire units to defend your hold.
Just, be careful as you get deeper though as the black joker is waiting. Drawing this card releases an ancient monstrosity, a randomly generated beast that needs a well stocked army and hold to defeat. 
The Story of Blood Fate Hold
The hold was off to a rough start as their chosen site led straight into the lair of the mud goblin clan, Rushk. The initial group of soldiers sent with the expedition where wiped out in this surprise attack.
Deciding that bad luck doesn't just strike once, they built a spike wall to defend their stairwell. A good choice as the next pick strike revealed a hive of cave wasps. Some miners perished but the overzealous wasps dashed themselves upon the spike wall.
Finally, Blood Fate was started, a barracks built just beyond the hive. It's honey would sustain the expedition and our new soldiers would have somewhere to stay while the miners delved deeper.
A string of good luck found trade goods and resources by the plenty and so they built a stewpot kitchen to hearten the fighting spirits of the soldiers, a shrine to bless their good luck, and finally, a stairwell to descend deeper.
The old adage of "fool me once" had become mantra for Blood Fate as they focused their efforts on defence. Rock fall traps on the stairwell, and a dead dwarf alarm that would warn of any approaching threat.
Their militaristic efforts where rewarded as after ignoring a buried temple (who knows what god it was built to), they broke through to a structure. A cavernous mansion filled with chandeliers, suits of armour, and a blood stained altar. A vampire queen's coterie. Her thralls poured from the shadows, overwhelming the miners and marching through the hold at their dark mistresses behest.
The boulder trap dashed the first zealous few on the stairs, weakening their numbers. The stew heartened soldiers fought bravely, managing to strike down all but one. The vampire queen herself. One soldier swore an oath to the gods and launched himself in a frenzy of spinning axes, injuring her before having his head torn from his shoulders. His sacrifice was not in vain however as his bravery bought the reinforcements called by the dead dwarf alarm time to arrive. 
Blood Fate Hold reeks of death and garlic, they say a fool is someone who doesn't learn from past mistakes and these dwarves are no fools. Every room is decorated in holy symbols to gods old and new and once a year the dwarves let blood in a rememberance ritual called Vampik.

RISE takes the DELVE engine and flips it on its head, putting you in the blood encrusted boots of a dungeon keeper as you build your dungeon, summon/grow/hire minions, and dig your way to the surface and your inevitable domination. Along the way you'll be challenged by powerful adventurers, other dungeons, and more. Will you be strong enough to keep your treacherous minions under control and defeat the forces of good? Or will you be overthrown and forgotten?

updates.update_content:
Hey everyone, thanks to your amazing support last year, I've decided to come back and do Zinequest again. This time I've put together a solo journalling RPG called Apothecaria. Like DELVE my focus is on Emergent Narrative and leaving you with a physical thing that is uniquely yours. In this case, a journal full of stories and potion recipes.
If that tickles your fancy, come check it out: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/diamondblood/apothecaria

Finally, after such a difficult year, the final part of the DELVE Kickstarter has landed. You should have an email from Backerkit with your UMBRA: Stations files. This expansion brings station management, tactical ship exploration, alien merchants, and loads of new rooms to UMBRA.
As usual, if you enjoy the game, I would massively appreciate comments and ratings over at https://blackwellwriter.itch.io/umbra-stations-expansion 
And, as of Monday, everyone who responded to the Backerkit before the deadline (and even quite a few who responded afterwards) have had their orders shipped. Thank you all for your patience... I was very optimistic with my initial dates and have learned a LOT from this Kickstarter.

Hey Everyone,
As many of you will have saw, the Backerkit survey deadline was the 15th of October and we're now more than a month past it. If you're one of the people who backed for physical copies and haven't completed the survey yet, you have until the 1st of December but I won't be holding copies back and there's a chance they sell out if you leave it too long.
For everyone who got their surveys in late, I'm packing tonight and shipping in the morning.

Hey everyone,
I've just made a Facebook group for people to share their holds, dungeons, and colonies to. Come tell me the story of how you blew an ancient monstrosity to pieces with your clever cannonade or how you delved too deep and unleashed a powerful lich who crushed your defences.
Join the group here: https://www.facebook.com/groups/delvemaps

I've had a few payments get flagged as fraudlent (which refunds you and charges me £15 each time). The payment on your bill will be made to Backerkit, BlackwellWriter, or just Blackwell. Please, don't dispute that as fraudlent unless you have other reason to.
If you have disputed, then sadly it's going to be February before the banks make a decision and I can't ship your copies until then.

The plan for today is to get the rest of the envelopes counted and posted so if you got your details in for the original Backerkit cut off date, yours will be sent out pretty soon.
If you missed the Backerkit cut off date but got your info in later, don't worry I'll be making my way round and getting yours sent out later in the week.
And if you still haven't got your info in and needed to, time is running out! If you don't complete the Backerkit by the 15th of November, I'll... I'll... to be honest I don't know, probably donate them to zine libraries or convert their value into digital community copies. So hurry up or charity will be done!

Good news Sweden, I've managed to sort the address problem :) 
If you got your Backerkit survey in on time and your card was successful then your copies are packed and addressed and ready... but we have to wait until the 29th to get the money and get them shipped. Which is a pain.
But, as of now, all the people that got in on time are ready!

So, after 2 days of gruelling labour we've managed to get basically every copy packed and are currently up to the Ks.
Now for the grumble worthy news. I can't get your shipping payments until the 29th so I can't really get things out the door until then. But as soon as the money comes in on the 29th, I'll be making new friends at the post office with ~1000 envelopes to post (: 
Oh, and I will unfortunately need to contact a fair number of people to confirm addresses as the spreadsheet has taken certain characters and mangled them.

Hey everyone!
UMBRA has hit the Itch.io store page and all 3 games are now available for download through Backerkit. So you should get an email with your download link in the next few hours.
As for surveys, they are now locking, with a final notice for any last minute changes. If you haven't got your survey completed yet, please let me know ASAP.
The pledge manager will lock the orders tomorrow and charge cards the day after so if you're one of the 140 people who haven't done it yet who needs to do it, best be quick!

campaign.story:
What is UNCONQUERED?
UNCONQUERED is a beginner-friendly, rules-light, bronzepunk swords & sorcery & sandals & sci-fi fantasy tabletop RPG, inspired by classic pulp serials such as Savage Sword of Conan, Flash Gordon, and John Carter of Mars, the Dying Earth genre, the  Dark Souls video game series, and webcomics such as Kill Six Billion Demons and Necropolis. Players generate character through a simple yet diverse lifepath-style character creation system, at each stage learning more about the infinite Loom they inhabit. Before long, they'll be undertaking mythic and perilous journeys through a decaying, waning universe of fading Gods, strange realities, and the dizzying remains of strange and wondrous civilizations.
What's in this Book?
UNCONQUERED will feature art by Peter Violini!
The UNCONQUERED book will contain the core rules for the UNCONQUERED RPG; full character creation tables with over 100 unique randomly-generated or selected options to create fully-developed, unique and interesting characters; tips for running a great game of UNCONQUERED; dozens of charts and tables of esoterica and miscellanea to develop a living, breathing, infinite Loom; and a setting guide, bestiary and starting adventure for the Jewelled Sands Of Zun Rüt, an introductory Sphere to allow new players the opportunity to play immediately . 
Creating an UNCONQUERED Character
Character creation in UNCONQUERED can be as complex as a tree of choices or as simple as rolling 10d6 in order.
UNCONQUERED character creation follows a lifepath system, whereby players will generate their characters randomly or through selection of several stages of development: where they were born, their culture and social strata, the omens of their birth, a brief story of their life thus far, their occupation, and a significant event that set them on the path of adventuring.
Birthplace examples from just one of many Spheres.
Each d6 list reveals a little more about the characters, allowing players and GMs to procedurally generate or carefully create unique and varied characters in only a few minutes. Each choice made or rolled bursts with the suggestion of a vast, living Loom and hints at how characters might inhabit it and move through it.
Examples of cultural backgrounds and social strata.
Each step gives the players  role-playing prompts, mementos of home, and cultural attire and armaments that combine to create fully developed, unique characters. These character creation rules are an excellent way for a Chronicler to generate quick and easy NPCs to further populate your games!
Examples of playable lineages.
Examples of personalized mementos.
Occupation tables for potential adventurers.
Individual-Based Experience
Characters in UNCONQUERED don't earn experience and progress themselves in the traditional, "kill monsters, acquire gold" manner - players generate or choose pairs of XP triggers that match and develop aspects of their personalities, based on birth omens and the stories of their lives thus far.
Birth omens and associated XP triggers.
A Rules-Light Framework
UNCONQUERED uses a flexible, rules-light mechanical toolkit that allows the action, intrigue and adventure to keep flowing without needing to constantly check the rulebook! Based on the KNAVE toolkit by Ben Milton, UNCONQUERED allows for a depth of customization and personalization for long-time TTRPG veterans and is intuitive and easy for first-time players. UNCONQUERED is also fully compatible with the toolkits and bestiaries of other OSR games such as KNAVE, Maze Rats, Basic Fantasy RPG, B/X, or AD&D/OD&D.
A rules-lite system that is easy to pick up on.
A Million, Million Spheres
 The UNCONQUERED book will feature all manner of tables, charts and passages of history, myth, rumor and lore to help players and Chroniclers develop their own versions of the infinite Loom and the million million Spheres within. A universe rich with culture and flavor awaits exploring!
Dozens of tables and charts to develop your own infinite Loom.
The Chronicler's Handbook
 A section of the UNCONQUERED book is dedicated to GM tips for new and experienced Chroniclers alike to help run the best adventures for you and your friends. Tools from the TTRPG Safety Toolkit by Kienna Shaw and Lauren Bryant-Monk are included to assist players and Chroniclers on techniques to build effective communication and trust at the table, ensuring everyone is having fun, is comfortable, and feels safe.
Chronicler goals from the Chronicler's Handbook section.
Who are We?
Monkey's Paw Games is an independent tabletop role-playing game publisher based out of Montreal, Canada.
UNCONQUERED is written by Nicholas Masyk, along with the help of a hand-picked cast of amazing writers, designers, illustrators, editors, and consultants.
Logo courtesy of Highland Paranormal Society
What is SWORDDREAM?
 *DREAM stands against hate & prejudice in all forms. We seek to actively oppose bigotry & harassment in gaming communities. We create kind spaces.
 *DREAM works to be radically inclusive. We seek to support and encourage creators, GMs, players, and organizers from marginalized groups. And we seek to get better at this all the time.
 *DREAM encourages the use of sensible tools for communication and consent. This includes both conversational consent (in community spaces) and safety tools (at the table).
 *DREAM opposes harassment and strives for non-toxic discourse. We value best intentions, we call in before calling out, and we start discussions before we make accusations. We seek to empower everyone to curate their space. Above all, we engage sincerely.
 *DREAM values creators & their work. We support equitable pay for professional creators and fair treatment for hobbyists.
 *DREAM values a DIY approach to creation. We question gatekeeping, we take alternative approaches when traditional publishing models fail, and we believe anyone can make great games.
 *DREAM values experimentation in game design & worldbuilding.
 *DREAM isn't defined by, but is interested in: anti-canons, emergent story, generative worlds, kitbashing, non-violent play options, and more. And it's fine if some of these things contradict each other!
 There is no one *DREAM. Anyone who commits to these principles is *DREAMing.
Where Does the Money Go?
Note: to each of these costs is a 20% buffer for Kickstarter fees, other overhead costs/expenses, and a setback buffer.
$0.20/word for contributing writers.
$20-25 per physical edition sold for hardcover color printing, based on total copies printed.
$30/hr for editing.
$80/hr for cultural consulting.
$100 for additional consulting/development.
$350 for a custom cover by Peter Violini.
$1000 for additional artwork.
Rewards
 Digital Copy: All backers will receive a digital download coupon on itch.io for a fully illustrated PDF version of the UNCONQUERED game book.
 Physical Copy: Backers at this level will also receive a fully illustrated, color hardcover print copy edition of the UNCONQUERED game book.
 Signed Copy: Backers at this level will receive a signed hardcover print copy edition of the UNCONQUERED game book. This level is for backers who particularly believe in this project and want something a little extra for their extra support.
Community Copies
Monkey's Paw Games is a strong believer in the Community Copies program. There will be a number of such copies available for backers from marginalized communities and/or those experiencing poverty, allowing you a digital or print copy at a discount. Every ten backers will unlock an additional digital copy.
Stretch Goals
 $13,000 USD: All of the contributing writers will be paid $0.25/word, and editors, consultants and developers will be paid 50% more.
 $16,000 USD: Our art budget will increase from $1000 to $1500! We're still going to commission the same amount of art, but our artists are going to be paid 50% more!
Social Goals
100 Retweets GOAL COMPLETE!: at 100 re-tweets of this tweet, I will expand the Magic Items List to include 50 more items, for 150 items total!
 100 Shares: at 100 shares of this post, I will expand the Spells List to include 50 more spells, for 150 spells total!
Shipping
Shipping for both domestic and international orders will be charged separately from the cost of each tier, calculated after the campaign closes, collected individually based on address at time of fulfillment. This will most likely be handled through shipping tickets created on Gumroad.
Media
Join the Monkey's Paw Games Discord server to discuss the game and learn about new content! 
Become a Monkey's Paw Games Patron to stay abreast of future UNCONQUERED releases, and other Monkey's Paw games!
The Team
Nicholas Masyk (@nicholasmasyk)is  a biracial role-playing game designer and longtime GM from Montreal, Quebec, Canada, and creator of Monkey's Paw Games. His games seek to inject anti-colonial, anti-racist, and anti-fascist narratives into the lens of science fiction, fantasy, and horror through projects such as numerous Trophy Dark Incursions as well as his own works such as UNCONQUERED, Chalice, and SMILE, which can be found at https://monkeys-paw-games.itch.io/.
Amr Ammourazz (@ammourazz) is an Egyptian RPG designer, writer, and all around nerd. Their goal in games is to inject a diverse perspective into anything they get their hands on. You can find out about their projects on twitter, and play a few of their games at ammourazz.itch.io/.
Ben Scerri is a non-binary bisexual Maltese Australian tabletop- and video game producer, writer, designer, and community builder, living in Melbourne, Australia. Their work focuses on themes of diaspora, disability/critical illness, self-actualization, and found family, often through the lenses of their ethnic and queer intersections. When not writing for or about games, they're likely talking about language, cooking, baking, folklore, and/or fashion.
Jan Martin is a Mi'kmaw Graphic Designer, Writer and Publisher living in New Brunswick, Canada. Their work explores worlds absent from, or completely overtaken by Capitalism and Colonialism. Currently they are pitching a game to publishers called Backwards Spear. It explores North America as though it was never fully Colonized. Find them on twitter @hellotenbear or https://www.tenbear.com/
Vincent Smith (@DichotomusPrime) is a West-Indian Canadian game designer, voice actor, and professional gamemaster of 5+ years residing in Guelph, Ontario. With an emotions-first philosophy towards game design, his focus is on providing tools for inspiring and enabling both GM's and players to chase their wildest creative ideas at the table.
Monkey's Paw Games Stands With Kickstarter United

campaign.story:
Candlelight is a role playing game about the restless spirits of treasure hunters reckoning with their dark past and seeking hope in a haunted forest that wants to trap them there. It is a one-shot, rules-light game, focusing on collaborative and thematic storytelling and is designed to be flexible in how you bring it to the table:
An epilogue for any fantasy game following character death - especially a TPK!
A world-building prologue for any game needing a haunted forest or other cursed place. 
A stand-alone game exploring themes of dark fantasy and supernatural horror - with a glimmering of hope and redemption. 
(Test print. Dice, adventuring equipment and escape from the forest not included).
 Candlelight is a game for 1 or more players and a GM. Character creation is simple, taking place as part of the game introduction. The game uses six-sided dice of 2 colors (light and dark) and each session runs approximately 3-4 hours. While the game is based on dark fantasy and horror themes, conversations about player expectations and the use of safety tools are encouraged to best fit the tone of game you want at the table. Ghost stories can be bleak, dreadful, terrifying - but also reflective, inspiring and even hopeful. The paths you choose through the forest are up to you and your group.
Candlelight is Rooted in Trophy, using the core system of Trophy Dark to tell as story of desperate characters pushing their luck in a place that constantly threatens to overwhelm them. The key difference here is that the characters have already met their doom - while Trophy Dark progresses through a series of Rings and escalating horror, Candlelight starts at that final Ring where the characters have just died. It is at the dark heart of the forest that they will begin their journey, retracing the steps they took while living, seeking hope and an escape from the forest before they become a monstrosity that haunts it forever.
To explore a wide range of fantasy-horror stories, Candlelight is compatible with any of the incursions (scenarios) from Trophy Dark. Detailed instructions are included for adapting your favorite Trophy Dark incursion for Candlelight, and any character creation options from Trophy are easily transferrable to Candlelight.
The following are some of the core mechanics adapted from Trophy Dark:
 Occupations are now Memories, skills or significant experiences from your life.
Your Doom is similar to a Background (an insight gained from the way you died).
 Rituals are now Dirges, terrible outpourings of anguish and dread that have the power to alter the physical world around the spirits.
 Risk Rolls work much the same, although spirits are much weaker without their physical bodies...
 Ruin Rolls are called Reckonings and work similarly - occasionally used as flashbacks to learn what occurred during the failed incursion of the treasure hunters.
 Devil’s Bargains are now Desperate Prayers, offered to the darkness without knowing what ancient entities of the forest may answer - or what the cost of drawing their attention might be.
 Hope and Despair are elements adapted from Quietus, with Despair replacing Ruin, and Hope offering a glimpse at something like redemption. 
 Reduction Rolls are called Haunts, which have a chance to lower your Despair. 
 Conditions are called Manifestations which result from increases to either Hope or Despair.
You may have noticed the looming growth of the Trophy RPG on Kickstarter. Candlelight joins the scene as another way to explore this fantastic game. 
Candlelight is a complete, stand alone game which includes rules for play, tips for running the game and a series of tables to quickly add character creation and story options to your game with little preparation.
Sample layout and test print
Sample layout and test print
Sample layout and test print
Candlelight will be printed in black and white at an estimated 32 pages. Successfully reached stretch goals will expand the page count. The zine will contain:
Rules for the game, a blank Character Sheet, tips for running the game including principles of play and safety tools.
Detailed instructions for adapting Trophy Dark incursions for Candlelight.  
Expanded tables for Dirges (Rituals), Drives of the spirit characters, options for your Doom (backgrounds), Memories (including extensive options related to relationships, identities and roles), Lures (story threads to draw the spirits out of the forest), Beliefs of the Afterlife and many more evocative elements to inspire your game. 
Design and layout featuring the atmospheric textures of B. Zentz. 
 Additional tables by guest authors (UNLOCKED!)
Gorgeous ink illustrations by Ezra Rose - with additional art (UNLOCKED!)
Streamlined options for adapting characters from D&D and other games.
An introductory scenario for playing the game.
art by Ezra Rose
Shipping - worldwide shipping is included in the cost of all physical pledges. As the printed zines will be under 3.5 oz shipping weight, they are considered letter-size for First-Class Mail International so this should be relatively straightforward.  
A game of Candlelight begins with a brief introductory story created during a conversation between players and GM, outlining the recent events which led to the death of the treasure hunters. Each player then begins character creation by naming their character and establishing how they died (their Doom). Answering a few more prompts, they will list a few significant skills or occupations they had when alive (Memories) and what they hope to resolve by escaping the forest (Drive). As the game progresses, players will attempt to enact powerful changes on their environment by unleashing Dirges. They will face Reckonings when they come across something from their dark past, increasing their Hope or Despair as a result. Eventually one of these states will reach a tipping point and signal the epilogue for that character.
Characters are built in much the same way as Trophy Dark. While many terms have been adapted for a game of desperate spirits instead of living treasure hunters, Candlelight encourages you to use your favorite Rituals, Occupations, Backgrounds and Drives from any Trophy Dark incursion.  
(Sample layout and character sheet)
FUNDED! $1200 - The Awakening. Additional tables for Candlelight, providing vivid details to include in your game and written by some fantastic guest authors:
 Omens and Portents by Sarah Rowan  
 Obstacles and Attachments by Madeleine Ember  
 Cursed Treasures by Nicholas Masyk 
FUNDED! $1700 - The Journey. More tables for Candlelight written by guest authors, full of evocative examples to inspire your game:
 Strange Denizens of the Forest by Linda Codega 
 Manifestations of Hope and Despair by Oli Jeffrey  
 Ancient Entities and their Demands by Jamila R. Nedjadi  
FUNDED! $2200- The Revelation. Additional Art! 
Candlelight will feature MORE fantastic ink illustrations by Ezra Rose.
FUNDED! $2700- The Reckoning. A new Exodus (Incursion) will be written specifically for Candlelight by Gabriel Robinson, designed as an introduction to the game.
FUNDED! $3200 - Song of the Forest - Character Resurrection Guide and Theme Song 
 Candlelight will include a guide for converting your character from D&D and other games, with tables written by Natalie Ash. This is intended as an easy entry point for groups playing a campaign, players new to role playing games, or anyone wanting to revisit a character from a past game (living or otherwise). 
 The game will also include a unique Candlelight theme song by Skye Zentz, sent to backers at all pledge levels as an MP3. That’s right - an RPG zine with its own song! Skye will write and record a haunting, atmospheric ballad narrating the journey of spirits through the haunted forest. The song will provide an introduction to the game and will be a great way to set the tone for play. 
FUNDED! $3700 - Share the Story - Increased Pay for All Contributors to Candlelight, plus Set of Compact Character Sheets 
At this level, all Candlelight contributors (art, layout and stretch goal writers) will receive an increase in pay (approximately 20%) - this project would not have got this far without their contributions!
Additionally, all physical reward tiers ($12 and above) will come with a printed set of 4 compact character sheets for your table. These will be printed separately from the zine itself, double-sided for easy distribution at the table. These sheets will be included in the PDF as well for easy printing and copying.
FUNDED! $4200 - additional character options by Madeleine Ember and professional editing for Candlelight!
$5000 - Solo Variant. Candlelight will include an option for solo play, using it's introspective themes to write your own tragic tale as you revisit the memories of a doomed character and find your way to some form of hopeful resolution.
 33 "Remembrance" Retweets - Pre-generated Characters. 
Upon reaching 33 retweets of the Candlelight project page, the game will include a series of sample characters for Candlelight, thematically grouped together in parties for quick play (and narratively connected backgrounds).
How to Participate: Retweet the project link for Candlelight and tell us about the death of one of your characters from any roleplaying game, using the following format:
"I was (name/title). I was known for (famous deed or memorable quirk). 
In the end, my doom was (manner of death). Who will remember me? #ToTheLost" bit.ly/candlelight-rpg" 
 (We are currently at 10/33 retweets with character remembrances!)
art by Ezra Rose
Read a preview of Candlelight by Clayton Notestine on The Explorer's Company here: https://www.theexplorersco.com/home/2020/candlelight/zinequest
Reviews:
"After a game of Trophy Dark where everyone dies, Candlelight is the perfect answer to the question: What now? And not only is the answer elegant and satisfying, it provides a surprising point of light in a world otherwise wrapped in darkness. Fans of ghost stories of all kinds will find much to love in Candlelight."
-Jesse Ross, Creator of the Trophy RPG
“We ended up publishing three of Gabriel’s Trophy Dark scenarios because they are really, really good. Gabriel is a terrific, evocative writer. There’s a lot of poetry in everything he writes, and I can’t wait to see Candlelight.” 
-Jason Cordova, Founder of The Gauntlet and publisher of the Trophy RPG.
"Candlelight is a ghost-story game, but told in a completely new direction: from the perspective of the ghosts and backwards in time. By focusing on the characters reckoning with events that have already happened, it enacts a story that goes beyond the story-focused questions of agency and narrative, and confronts what those actions mean in the context of a character’s identity and the often-overlooked contradictions identity holds.  In a fun and engaging way, Candlelight reminds us that death is not the end of story; there is the question of what that story meant that remains to be explored."
-Natalie Ash, Ember and Ash Games
"Such a thoughtful and emotionally evocative theme- by playing as ghosts, we get to be gently reminded of how very alive we are."
-Skye Z. (playtester) 
 Gabriel Robinson (writing and game design) carries memories of dark forests and tide pools from his childhood in the Pacific Northwest. He lives in Norfolk, VA with his wife and their small creatures, where he writes, works in healthcare and runs therapeutic role playing games. His incursions Gift of the Sea, The Forbidden Archives and Temple of the Sky are being published in the Trophy RPG, currently on Kickstarter.
 Ezra Rose (art) is an illustrator, zinester & mixed/multi-media creator living on a small farm in Western Massachusetts with queer chosen family. Their art explores monsters, magic, queer/trans identity and Jewish culture, celebrating the marginal and connecting to the symbols and stories of both past and present. Ezra's work has appeared in tabletop games, comics anthologies, and other small/indie press. | ezra-rose.com / @magpietongue |
B. Zentz (design and layout) became a fan of graphic design through album cover art, magazine layout, punk rock fanzines, action figure packaging, skateboard graphics, and rave & club flyers. He has worked as a freelance designer, copywriter, and in-house designer. Despite the state of digital world domination, he remains stubbornly committed to printed matter.
Stretch Goal Writers: 
 Sarah Rowan (@EchoingLaughter) is a game designer who likes writing tabletop games of all varieties, LGBT representation, buff sword women, and cryptic poetry. She has a degree in Game Design, a black belt in Tae Kwon Do, and an awesome wife who inspires her daily.
 Madeleine Ember (@MadeleineEmber) writes, illustrates, and generally makes a nuisance of herself at any opportunity. She lives with her partner and two cats in Camas, WA; where they together create many strange things.
 Linda Codega (@_linfinn) is a queer, nonbinary writer living by a mountain in the Hudson Valley. They are a speculative fiction author and narrative game designer. Their work has appeared in various anthologies, magazines, and blogs, and you can find a selection of their games on their itch page: http://lhcodega.itch.io.
 Nicholas Masyk (@nicholasmasyk) (he/him) is a roleplaying game designer and longtime GM from Montreal, Quebec, Canada, and creator of Monkey's Paw Games. His games seek to inject anti-colonial, anti-racist and anti-fascist narratives into the lens of science fiction, fantasy, and horror through projects such as numerous Trophy Dark Incursions as well as his own works such as UNCONQUERED, Chalice, and SMILE, which can be found at https://monkeys-paw-games.itch.io/. 
 Oli Jeffrey (@ojeffery) is a games designer and fan of all things macabre and maudlin. Yes, he was a teenage goth. He's best known for the RPG Quietus, and is a frequent contributor to Codex magazine. Look for his upcoming project Night Reign coming to Zinequest!
 Jamila R. Nedjadi  (@temporalhiccup) believes in the power of ghost stories, and in telling these stories together. They have written a few ghostly story games, as well as other games that focus on emotional connection and intuitive creativity. You can check out their games at https://temporalhiccup.itch.io/ or support them through https://www.patreon.com/swordqueengames 
 Natalie Ash is one-half of the creative team behind Ember+Ash, a small-press publisher of rpg content. When not serving her two feline overlords, she creates worlds that are broken, beautiful, and entirely terrible. She talks about RPGs and other nonsense at @theNatalieAsh.
 Skye Zentz (@skyezentz) is a professional songwriter and music educator who has served as composer and lyricist for the Emmy nominated WHRO environmental  series “Green Beats”. Skye teaches songwriting & ukulele at The Muse Writers Center in Norfolk Virginia, and loves iced coffee, a good cheese plate, and all friendly, fluffy creatures.
Candlelight, and my dive into writing for role playing games, has been extensively inspired by Trophy. Much gratitude to Jesse Ross for creating such an elegant and evocative game and encouraging others to contribute their ideas and create hacks of their own.
 This project also would not have been launched without the support of Jason Cordova and The Gauntlet. Codex magazine has been an inspiration for creating the kind of games I'm passionate about sharing with others and I am very excited for Candlelight. Thank you for supporting my work and the many other Trophy-related projects underway.
Thanks also to the many fantastic writers in the Trophy and indie RPG community for your inspired writing, thoughtful feedback and encouragement! I look forward to our future collaborations.
Thanks to Skye for such grounded support and for being a guiding light during the times I have found myself walking a more winding path than necessary.

Hi everyone! I hope you're all safe and well in the new year. While it continues to be a trying time for all of us, to say the least, I hope you've been able to play some games with friends online and continue to find things that bring you joy.
On that note, I'm excited to share that my next project, TOKEN, is coming to Zinequest on February 9th! 
TOKEN is a GM-less duet game Rooted in Trophy and inspired by dark fairytales and tragic ballads. It tells the story of a failed hero entering a haunted place and the transformed monster who dwells there, each seeking each other for reasons that change as the story unfolds. Both characters offer each other tokens symbolizing their intentions, and as they discover the bonds they share in common, their drive changes. The game ends when they meet at last, and both characters narrate the epilogue. Like Candlelight, TOKEN will be a deeply atmospheric and collaborative game which tells beautiful and tragic stories. I've got a fantastic team working on this project and think you're really going to love it.

Hi everyone, A quick update here to mention that print zines have begun to arrive at their destinations—its been wonderful to see your posts of physical copies. If you have a moment to share pictures of yours, review the game on Itch.io or talk about how your session of Candlelight went, I'd love to know. Thanks again for your patience with shipping, and please message me if you have any issues with your rewards!
Secondly, as a member of Cold Hearth Collective (https://www.coldhearthcollective.com/our-mission), I'm very excited to announce Alchemy (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/coldhearthcollective/alchemy-1?ref=clipboard-prelaunch), a hardbound collection of alchemically-themed incursions for Trophy Dark, launching 9/22/2020 on Kickstarter! Alchemy will feature original Trophy Dark incursions written by a team of super talented writers including: Amalie Mckee (https://twitter.com/MaenadMags), Madeleine Ember (https://twitter.com/MadeleineEmber), Michael Van Vleet (https://twitter.com/signalstation), Natalie Ash (https://twitter.com/theNatalieAsh), Pam Punzalan (https://twitter.com/TheDovetailor), Nicholas Masyk (https://twitter.com/nicholasmasyk), Speak the Sky ( https://twitter.com/SpeaktheSky), Jamila Nedjadi (https://twitter.com/temporalhiccup) and yours truly.
