campaign.story:
The Game
Oligarchy is a game of political folly, Rooted in Trophy. You play as rotten bastards: corrupt politicians, decadent aristocrats, and other greedy elites. You are each determined to maximize your own wealth and comfort while your actions tear society apart around you. Eventually, society will tolerate your abuses no more. But the iron confidence that is your privileged birthright makes you certain you will avoid that doom. You'll do anything to make sure you get yours (and get away with it).
Oligarchy includes three incursions, storylines to follow as your rotten bastards careen toward a doom they think they'll avoid:
 Eye of a Needle (Theme: Collapse) They keep saying it's the End Times. That the Final Judgement hangs over all men's heads like Damocles' sword. Well, no Seven-Headed Dragon will keep you from fleecing the rubes as long as they let you. So what if the signs are becoming visible? They were always there if you had the eyes to see them.
 Sleep Furiously (Theme: Greed) The more you accumulate the better you feel. You are a dragon among your hoard. Extracting and exploiting free lands and free hands, doing what the Market demands. You love, no, you LIVE for that. Where there's demands you will find the supply. Anything is a commodity if you're flexible enough.
 Trail of Plenty (Theme: Promises) Elections are a hopeful time, and the fine wool of hope makes a fine blind over ones eyes. This campaign makes many promises as the dust chokes half the nation and the floodwaters rise. Each one is a mask over your scheming and disdain.
Decadent Elites
You conduct your sordid business and pork-barrel legislation using the excellent framework provided by Trophy Dark, a tabletop roleplaying game system by Jesse Ross. The basics are simple: when you take a greedy action, state what you hope will happen and build a pool of light and dark dice based on fictional circumstances and what you're willing to risk. Roll and take the highest result to find out your fate. Did you get away with your exploit? Did you make things worse? Did the consequences of your actions bring you to Ruin? Play to find out.
Everything you need to understand the core rules of the Trophy system is freely available in a System Reference Document. Click the image below or visit TrophyRPG.com to read them for yourself
Click above to visit Trophy's website.
Trophy is now on Kickstarter!
The Gauntlet is crowdfunding a series of Trophy books until February 23, 2020. By backing their campaign, you can explore the doomed world of this system across three volumes:
 Trophy Dark, a one-shot game of doomed treasure hunters and psychological horror, set in and around a vast, ancient, and accursed forest.
 Trophy Gold, a campaign game of old-school dungeon delving. Your treasure hunters are not doomed, but merely desperate.
 Trophy Loom, a system-agnostic setting book that guides you through the steps necessary to bring the bleak world of Trophy into awful life.
Click here to visit the Trophy Kickstarter page to learn more about the dark tales you might tell with your play group.
The Campaign
We're on the campaign trail to build a constituency of backers to help us bring Oligarchy into its own awful life. The backer levels are simple:
 Electorate ($1+): You've given us the vote of your dollar, the only vote that matters. In exchange, you receive our thanks and nothing more.
 Digital Lobbyist ($10+): You've paid to play, and so you shall enjoy some basic fruits. You will receive our thanks and a PDF copy of the Oligarchy RPG zine. You will also receive a print-ready file you can send to any print shop to make your own physical copy.
 Print Lobbyist ($20+): You've made a substantial investment. You deserve a substantial kickback. In addition to the rewards of the Digital Lobbyist tier, you'll also receive a print copy of the Oligarchy RPG zine via standard mail.
 Esteemed Donor ($50+): Only the finest treatment is due to such a generous benefactor as you. You get everything from the Digital Lobbyist tier plus four print copies of the Oligarchy RPG zine via standard mail. Buy enough copies for everyone in your play group and save $30!
The end product is a half-letter size zine printed on multipurpose copy paper with a heavy card-stock cover. Filled with darkly beautiful engravings from the public domain, Oligarchy will leave a stain upon anyone's memory. 
Community Copies
Every person who backs our campaign at or above the Digital Lobbyist level creates one community copy that will be freely available on our Itch storefront when the game arrives there (estimated June 2020). Community copies help someone else grab a free copy if their budget doesn't enable them to pay the listed price. For this project, community copies on Itch will include a PDF copy of the game as well as the print-ready file.
The Ills of This World
No Stretch Goals?
As chief executives of this grand experiment, we the creators have legislated that all profits shall be shared between us. We do not cede the floor to counterargument or filibuster. If you have grievances, we are happy to serve by sending agents of our choosing to address your concerns.
Agents of our Enforcement
Campaign Staffers
Oligarchies thrive when power and control is shared among just a few elites. For our own, we have chosen three:
 Aaron Burkett (Writing, Fulfillment) is a narrative designer & podcaster from Houston, Texas. In addition to Oligarchy, he has contributed to Trophy Dark, Retropunk, Errant Deeds, and Monster of the Week. His work focuses on crime, opportunity, & the sins we do for dollars. You can follow Aaron on Twitter @APBurkett or on his blog at https://doomrides.blogspot.com.
 Eli Kurtz (Production, Writing) is a game designer, cartographer and podcaster. He's written games like The Summer Greening, Fireside Fables, The Blackwood Errantry Codex, and his current project, Errant Deeds: Tall Tales in the Blackwood. You can follow Eli on Twitter @ZapDynamic or at his website, MythicGazetteer.com.
 Dee Pennyway (Layout),the layout designer for Oligarchy, is a gamewright and award-winning layout designer. They have written and laid out several games for the Mnemonic fantasy setting, and designed layouts for games such as plot ARMOR, 99c Chamber of Death, and Mic Drop. You can follow Dee on Twitter @DeePennyway or on itchio at https://mnemonicrpg.itch.io/.
Fulfillment
PDF copies of Oligarchy will be fulfilled through Itch.io and DriveThruRPG.com.  You will select your preferred fulfillment source in your backer survey and download keys will be sent to you accordingly. Registering on either site is a free and easy process if you don't have an account already.
Print copies of Oligarchy will be mailed via standard mail in the US. International shipping is not available, but please note the print-ready file available in the Digital Lobbyist ($10+) tier. There is a $4 shipping charge for US customers in addition to your pledge. Both the pledge and shipping fee will be charged when the campaign ends. 
Digital fulfillment available through DriveThruRPG
Onward, to Victory!
Endorsements
As rotten oligarchs, we thrive on the pomp and symbol of accolades. Here are a few such decadent morsels offered to other Zine Quest 2 projects we're excited about:
 A Touch of Glamour, fey mayhem, as Powered by the Apocalypse.
 The Artefact, craft a unique magical item and play to find out how it changes as it passes through the hands of many different keepers.
 The Company, a game of corporate supernatural horror.
 Dish Pit Witches, a small RPG zine about gay witches who work in a restaurant, based on the Tunnel Goons system.
 The Last Place on Earth, a ZineQuest rpg of determination and hubris at the South Pole inspired by Robert F. Scott's fatal expedition.
 Palanquin, a zinequest roleplaying game about the Heir and her escape from a palace coup.
And special mention goes to our co-campaigners "rooted in Trophy" for Zine Quest 2:
 Candlelight (Feb 4), a one-shot RPG about restless spirits seeking hope
 MYCELIUM (Feb 2), four horrific allergen-based adventures for the Gauntlet's Trophy Dark RPG.
 Night Reign (Feb 14), a tabletop roleplaying game of stealth, guile, violence and devilry in a fantasy metropolis.
 Richter: The Rotting City (Feb 4), a system-agnostic city, Richter: The Rotting City, for tabletop-role-playing games.
More to come as their products launch!
Lastly, real oligarchs would never do this but we're proud to stand in solidarity with the workers of Kickstarter United, organizing with OPEIU Local 153. 
Kickstarter United
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Mythic Gazetteer has one successful Kickstarter campaign under its belt, delivered complete and on time. We're also Superbackers, so we've been able to study the triumphs and trials of dozens of Kickstarters. We're bringing that experience to bear in this project.

This is the first time the Mythic Gazetteer handles fulfillment for a project in-house. It's a manageably small project but unforeseen snags are bound to occur. We're working with local printers to provide the physical materials and binding the game with home-owned equipment. These costs are unlikely to change during our project timeline but technical issues may arise.

Our policy is always threefold: achievable goals, open communication, and honest work. We're compensating the folks involved generously. We'll be prompt in communicating all milestones and setbacks. And lastly, we've structured a project we're confident we can achieve.

The Mythic Gazetteer stands in solidarity with the workers of Kickstarter United, organizing with OPEIU Local 153. We believe in their collective power and we follow their lead. If that belief ever comes into conflict with our business here on Kickstarter: we stand with the workers.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
When you were young, you thought the great walls of Barrow Keep would keep you safe. But now you're coming of age, and you realize how many troubles have been inside these walls all along: duplicitous courtiers, treacherous kin, and puritanical heresy-hunters. How will you protect yourself and your friends?
Barrow Keep is a low-prep, old-school setting driven by playbooks and adaptable, easy-to-run scenarios. You play the young residents of the Keep, coming of age while dealing with mysteries, treacheries, and intrigues.
Inspiration & Compatibility
In summer 2018, my friend Maria Rivera asked why there weren't any old-school style games for a Game of Thrones-style setting. This project owes a lot to Maria's initial question and her commitment as a reader and playtester. The original game we ran with several other friends was deeply inspired by Beyond the Wall from Flatland Games, TSR's Known World Gazeteer series, and Whitehack by Christian Mehrstam.
As the project has continued through several campaigns and one-shots, it's grown past its Ice & Fire roots and been inspired by a wide range of writers of gothic, young adult, historical, and romantic fantasy, including Ellen Kushner, N.K. Jemisin, V.E. Schwab, Lois McMaster Bujold, Tamora Pierce, and Mercedes Lackey.
Barrow Keep is compatible with:
Old School Essentials from Necrotic Gnome 
Sharp Swords & Sinister Spells by Diogo Nogueira 
Thanks to stretch goals, we'll also be releasing materials compatible with:
Best Left Buried (Print, PDF) from SoulMuppet (See Questing Beast's review)
Trophy Gold/Rooted in Trophy (Kickstarter, Twitter) from The Gauntlet 
The Physical Zine
The 32-page zine includes:
Procedures for making your own Barrow Keep, giving each player choices about the Keep's rulers, attendants, and mysteries
GM advice and pointers focused on running the first session
A tour of Barrow Keep's locations, factions, and arcane technologies
A bestiary of the Keep's catacombs and the surrounding woods
OSR-compatible character and magic options
The Barrow Keep: Den of Spies cover by Minerva Fox
Digital Supplements
Along with the zine itself, everyone who backs Barrow Keep will get:
Seven OSR-style playbooks compatible with Old School Essentials and other OSR systems, including The Hostage, The Spy, The Wielder, The Lost Familiar, The Revenant, and The Wolf
Seven playbooks adapted for Sharp Swords & Sinister Spells, 2nd Edition 
Two scenarios set in Barrow Keep: "Treacherous Kin" and "The Changeling Spy," compatible with almost any OSR system
Handouts for players and GMs
Worksheets and a relationship map for creating your own custom version of Barrow Keep
Reserved PDFs, Watchful Advisers, and Knights Errant
We've set aside 25 copies of the PDF zine for $3 for backers who self-identify as students, members of marginalized communities, or experiencing financial hardship. Each backer at the Watchful Adviser or Knight Errant level adds 5 more reserved PDFs available at the discounted rate.
Stretch Goals
At $1,500 (Funded!), cover illustrator Minerva Fox will add four new pieces of art to the zine.
At $2,000 (Funded!), award-winning game designer Sharang Biswas will develop a new digital mini-zine supplement: A mysterious place in the woods where ghostly trains will take seekers to search for answers in the worlds beyond this one... for a price.
At $2,500 (Funded!),game designer David Castro will create a new PDF Playbook for Barrow Keep: the Foretold! Your birth was prophecied, but was it for good or ill?
At $3,000  (Funded!), Barrow Keep instigator and playtester Maria Rivera will create a new digital mini-zine supplement detailing the residents of The Crow's Nest, the home castle of a rival house.
At $3,500 (Funded!), Dave Cox, designer of A Rasp of Sand, will create a new digital mini-zine supplement exploring the strangers, guests, and other visitors who come to Barrow Keep seeking hospitality (and sometimes opportunities to make trouble).
 At $4250 (Funded!), Bill Roundy, aka The Bartoonist, will be creating print-at-home paper minis for Barrow Keep.  Bill's the creator of both Bar Scrawl and Hot Men of the Monster Manual (poster or book), and you can see free PDF versions of his minis for Modrons, Bullywugs, and Kobolds.
Social Media Goal (unlocked) Backers are choosing an additional system third system for Barrow Keep to support from three Creative Commons systems. Find the details and poll link in this backer-only update. The additional materials for system compatibility will be released digitally by December 2020.
At $5000 (funded), cartographer Abigail LaLonde (Patreon, Twitter) will create a Barrow Keep map pack with maps of The Great Hall, the archon's apartments, a lost crypt in the catacombs, and the upper portions of the Eastern Tower. I'll do a write-up of each map.
At 325 total backers (unlocked), I'll adapt the Barrow Keep playbooks for SoulMuppet Publishing's amazing game Best Left Buried, bring the total number of systems we're supporting to 4! These additional playbooks will be released digitally by December 2020.
At $6000 - The Final Stretch Goal!, we'll give everyone on the team a bonus!
Character Playbook & Scenario Pack Previews
Check out this video playlist with previews of five different Barrow Keep playbooks and a one of the scenario packs.

Help us get the word out! Share the pinned post from the Barrow Keep Twitter account, or ask the Barrow Keep bot one of the following and share the answer:

Make me a character!

Builders of the Keep
Richard Ruane (he/him), writing & design. Richard is the creator of Barrow Keep, Dark Designs in Verdigris, Moonlight on Roseville Beach, and Chronicles of the Spacejammer. An RPG editor in a previous life, he created R. Rook Studio in 2019. By day, he is an instructional designer and content developer living in Brooklyn, NY. Find him on Twitter, Itch, and DriveThru RPG.
Liza Cortright, layout & graphics. Liza is a Brooklyn-based graphic designer by day and TTRPG enthusiast by night. You can find examples of her work as a GM, player, and designer at ManaPot Studios.
Minerva Fox (she/her), illustration. You may know Minerva's work from such projects as Hearts of Wulin, Demigods, and her fan web-comic, Heavy Metal Sailor Moon. A lot of her inspiration comes from manga and western comics. She absolutely loves collaborating and bringing ideas to life with both physical and digital media. You can follow her on social media: @blue_troller on Instagram, Twitter, and Twitch!
Fiona Maeve Geist (she/her) & Jarrett Crader (he/him), editing. Jarrett and Fiona (MRC) are a duo of editors and founders of the MoonRat Conspiracy. Numinous Edition, and many others.

Sharang is currently working on the anthology Honey & Hot Wax: An Anthology of Erotic Art Games with Co-editor Lucian Kahn (expected 2020, Pelgrane Press). Check out his portfolio and follow him on Twitter and Itch.

Dave Cox (he/him), stretch goal writing. Dave is the creator of A Rasp of Sand and other tabletop games. Lover of all things design, aesthetic, and user experience. Find him on Twitter and Itch.

campaign.story:
Generations ago, humanity sowed the seeds of its own demise by exploiting the land and trying to control the powers of nature. Some tried to stop it, but not enough did. The earth’s systems broke down. The sun turned cities into kilns and the sea crept steadily inland. Millions of fish washed ashore, birds fell from the sky, and blight wiped out trees. Towering floods and withering droughts led to displacement and social collapse. Those who did the least to cause it suffered the most.
We only got one try — and we failed. 
Lost Roads is a fantasy role playing game that follows migrants on their journey through a harsh, unforgiving world. Humans, once rich with magic and resources, exploited nature beyond its means. Modern society collapsed, falling to a pre-medieval level of technology. Pockets of civilization now huddle within barren and twisted landscapes, connected by the Lost Roads—defunct, reclaimed pathways.
The player characters, driven out by climate disaster, travel the Lost Roads together in search of a place to call home. Each character has a role and an elemental domain—earth, fire, water, or air. They can use their magic to enhance or pervert nature to reach their goal; but harming the environment empowers a malevolent, supernatural Storm.
If you survive the Lost Roads and reach the Borderlands, journey’s end, you bring new hope. If you fail, humanity dries up and blows away like so much parched grain. You survive not just for yourself and those around you, but those who will come after. For without you, there are no roots from which a new society can flourish.
The game is designed for 2-5 players including a GM, and is inspired by The Road, A Quiet Place, Annihilation, Fast Color, and similar stories. It can be run as a one shot or a short campaign lasting 2-5 sessions.  
Lost Roads offers a new system to tell a unique tale of environmental trauma in a bygone, fantasy setting. This game is rooted in story-games of a similar tone, such as The Quiet Year, Versus Nature, Legacy Life Among the Ruins, and Downfall. Players can revel in rich, sensory narrative about their relationships, themselves, and the perilous world around them. But Lost Roads also draws inspiration from the stress and grit of mechanics that reward player ingenuity, character competency, and managing time and resources.
The system was built from the ground up to be highly modular. Play cycles fluidly through several phases with a push and pull between survival, sheltering, and moving on to new places.
Lost Roads uses an elegant D6 die pool system with varying degrees of success and failure, designed for exploring tense survival stories of eco-migrants and supernatural climate fiction. If you roll well, your Motif—a magic symbol inspired by nature—reveals hidden secrets.
 Download: A preview of how to make Survival Rolls.
When characters take refuge, simple scene-by-turn rules allows them to steal a moment to share a meal, a story, a dream. Then go forth once more to see if you can edge closer towards finding a home. 
The characters you play are the Tarnished—eco-migrants on a dangerous journey after society’s collapse. This marginalized group shares the gift of magic as it fades away. “Tarnished” is the image your detractors see: the wear and tear on your body and clothing, viewing your capabilities negatively rather than cherishing them.            
You gather hope to use magic.
Each character has a Role—a character’s walk of life. Each Role honors three vows, and fulfilling any of them increases Hope—what characters need to use magic, to stand firm against the Storm, and increase the community's prosperity. The four roles are: 
HEART. You devote yourself to the survival of those who need it most. Defend the vulnerable. Heal the injured. Deliver goods. 
KEEPER. The wilds guide your spirit, you must let both flourish. Defend wild places. Clean polluted spaces. Find and restore carbon sinks. 
RECLAIMER. You discover hope amidst fallen ruins and discarded scrap. Scavenge wreck and ruin. Shore up structures. Find and mark renewable resources. 
SEEKER. You seek paths like a meandering river. Branching, flexible, determined. Overcome obstacles. Blaze a trail for others to follow. Find and mark hideaways. 
A practitioner of earth magic.
Each character also chooses a Domain, a source of primeval magic which is fading from the world. Your domain influences what your magic does and how it manifests.
EARTH. A duality of trembling and unyielding. You have power to phase through solid barriers and form protective fields.
FIRE. An apparition of igniting and searing. You have power to emit a gush of flame or pass through fire unharmed.
WATER. A source tidal and unfathomable. You have power to raise waves of water or summon water spirits.
AIR. A shield, gusty and windswept. You have power to slash with wisps of wind or discharge electricity.    
Download: A preview of the Character Sheet, Seeker Role, and Earth Domain. 
Humanity is on a collision course with nature.
The Long Storm is a malevolent force of awesome, destructive power. A trembling vortex of metaphysical energy and dying magic. It embodies the decay of human society. You cannot defeat it. At best, you can only hide or escape from it.
Mistaken—creatures of eco-horror—are spawned in the eye of the Storm. These are chimeric horrors adapted to survive in extreme environments, hunting human prey.   
A complete game features five core phases:
In Worldbuilding, create a fantastic world together with flow and balance between human and natural communities, science, and nature. You create four Landmarks that stand the test of time, and draw them on a map. Then, you choose the Decay—a negative human trait such as ambition, greed, or wastefulness, that leads to environmental collapse.   
A map of the arctic tundra from our session with Emily Care Boss and Dane Fogdall.
Throughout a Traversal (scenario), you play in the wreckage that comes from balance lost, moving from one waypoint to the next by fulfilling the vows of your character. You weather the Storm and find help and hope in those around you, to seek possibilities of working with the world and each other, and risk losing it all.
When you Face Your Fears, you confront the Storm on an epic scale. These are gripping scenes of bravery and tragedy, as the landscape and entire community struggles against the elements. If characters spend enough Hope, they can withstand the destruction, or rebuild afterwards.
During the Hole Up phase you reach a landmark and the season draws to an end. Soak in community activity, human connection, relationships, and tending to the hurts of others. Let out the pain and grief people are bottling up—the antidote to feeling powerless.    
Play thematic scenes together at various landmark locations.
At this point, you can end the game if you’re playing a one-shot. Or, when you’re ready, begin a new Traversal and keep playing until you complete four seasons.
Finally, you reach Journey’s End to determine the epilogue. The outcome depends on your community's prosperity. Rejoice and reflect upon your year of travel together, or witness the final lash of the Long Storm. 
The zine will be a 60-page, 8 ½ x 5 ½ saddle-stitched booklet with a stunning sepia-colored cover image spanning both sides and interior pages printed in black ink. Illustrations will be done using traditional media.        
Cover art depicts the journey ahead and the hardships left behind.
Your pledge includes complete rules for building a post-fall world, creating Tarnished characters, playing through phases, and running the game using custom Traversals or creating your own.
Along with your pledge you will receive a PDF of the rules and a supplemental PDF including play aids, character sheets, Roles, Domains, a sample Traversal, and pre-generated characters to take your first steps. 
This short campaign lasts only 2 weeks — please help spread the word to launch the zine!    
Domestic shipping within the US is covered in the cost of the pledge. International shipping is charged separately (expected $4 USD). 
Session 0: Listen to Emily, Dane, and Ary as they create a post-fall society set in an arctic tundra and create characters. Preview the journey ahead on their map.
Session 1: Listen as they try to survive an unforgiving arctic landscape and regroup at an  ancient landmark made of dragon bones.
“Lost Roads is a love letter to a world on the brink of ruin, bound up with hope and horror. Play to see what heroism looks like on the other side of disaster.” —Emily Care Boss
“Lost Roads is a poignant game that manages to make a weighty topic both approachable and engaging. Characters can be powerful forces of hope and leadership, but the game asks you to make real choices and sacrifices to do so.” —Dane Fogdall
“Lost Roads has been such a relevant experience for me. Playing the game helped me to combine my worries about the state of the world (global inequalities, climate crisis) with my enthusiasm of telling stories of hope, friendship, and trust.” —Gerrit Reininghaus
“Lost Roads captures the fraught feelings of migrating away from home and allows players to share in the hope and adversity of the road. It allows us to reflect on what parts of home we take with us and which we leave by the wayside.” —Kyle Thompson
"I had a great time playing this game. I am someone who really enjoys games that draw clear inspiration from modern day issues, and this is the first game that I feel draws inspiration from subject matter related to climate change in a thoughtful manner. I want more games like this!" —Mikael Tysvær
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I am forging ahead on my first Kickstarter project, and with it come bumps in the road. Fortunately, I am surrounded by a team of highly experienced and talented professionals who have successfully blazed this trail before, and are here to support this project from start to finish. Your pledge covers the cost of art, layout, writing, editing, printing, and shipping. 

I’ve also taken extra measures to ensure a beautiful zine will reach your hands. 
• The rules are complete, minus editing and any stretch goals. 
• The game has been 5 years in the making, rigorously playtested based on feedback. 
• We’re working with a reputable printer using environmentally friendly products and practices, including soy-based ink and non-toxic printing processes.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
PARIAH: 
PSYCHEDELIC NEOLITHIC ANIMIST OLD SCHOOL ROLE PLAY
PARIAH is a zine that will enable you to set up and run a tabletop RPG pitching a band of outcast humans against a dangerous, primeval world of malevolent magic and capricious spirits... all in an A5 zine format produced for Zine Quest 2020.  
Pariah cover, white edition
 A complete game in and of itself, PARIAH is nonetheless easily adapted to your preferred old-school system. Indeed, many of the tools provided would be useful in any RPG you think suitable for the weird world of proto-neolithic roleplay!
OUTCASTS
The zine contains instructions for generating a band of pariahs - outcasts from mainstream human culture forced into the dangerous wilderness:
 Classless and level-less: develop characters through interaction with the environment, building alliances, developing skills and forging pacts with spirits.
 Lateral development: special curse templates that can lead your characters down unexpected paths including ghoul, jackalwere and blood-drinker... 
 Troupe play: control multiple characters, share them until they have grown into themselves, guide them as though you were their ancestral spirits.
 Build a community: foster young charges, care for the old, build the skill base of your pariah band, the better to face the challenges ahead.
 Die: lay down your lie for the good of your allies, knowing that your spirit can assist the fledgling band from the beyond!
ANIMISTS
Everything is alive: navigate a world where mountains, rivers, trees and even insects possess their own desires and ambitions!
Rules for generating spirits and determining their attitude to the PCs.
An original magic system based on conjuring, binding and bargaining with spirits.
PSYCHEDELIC   
This is a time of chaos: rationality has yet to force reality into a fixed form, and the boundaries between the corporeal and ethereal fluctuate...
Six psychedelic entheogens with unique properties!
Travel to the spirit world and find the true name of your enemies.
Create your own rituals, customs and traditions from afresh: this is a young world, and your characters are defining a new culture!
Sorcerer's Sage: smoke it, speak with the dead.
NEOLITHIC
The PCs begin in the wilderness, but already humans have begun to build the first cities: what are they doing their, and what force guides their hands?
Generate thriving, complex neolithic societies to navigate... or avoid!
Tables and generators for technological development and cultural advancement.
OLD SCHOOL
 Emphasis on player skill over character skill: play as the characters' guardian spirits,  not as the characters themselves.
 Highly lethal: get them out of danger quickly or be prepared to roll up another one.
 Sandbox style play: GMs are encouraged to create situations and challenges, not linear plots. Let the world come alive and happen around the PCs, with or without their participation!
 Rulings not rule: Take your pick of the guidelines within the zine, and fashion them to the tastes of your table. Use the tools for generating a world and populating it with danger and intrigue without being bound by mechanics.
 Familiar: Uses the traditional six ability scores and five saves so easy to pick up and easy to adapt to other old school systems.
ILLUSTRATION
Diagrams and illustrations throughout by Sofinho and Hoang Minh Nhat.
Professional illustrations by Abigail Lingford and Jef Cox: the more funding we get, the more illustrations they will provide!
TABLES
Tables galore including (but not limited to):
Magical side effects and mishaps
Mutations and curse templates
Reasons for exile - why your pariahs were banished.
Death and dismemberment
Wounds and infections
Palaeolithic equipment lists
Neolithic innovations generator
Random tribe generator
Wilderness encounters and generators
Neolithic city generator
Spirit reaction roll table (and spirit rewards table!)
PARIAH: ISSUE ONE
The printed zine will meet the following specifications:
Forty pages of monochrome text and illustration printed on A5 90 gsm paper. 
Bleached white cardstock (180 gsm)  cover 
As per zinequest 2020 guidelines, the zine is staple bound.
Make this happen and we'll make a second issue. 
Pariah cover (black)
 WHERE IS THE MONEY GOING?
The bulk of the money raised is used to pay our illustrators Jef, Abigail and Felicia (Nhat). The lead designers (Sofinho and Dzung) are not taking any payment for their work.
Shipping is included in all print orders, wherever you are in the world: there are no additional shipping or delivery fees.
Printing costs are our third largest expense. Currently we are planning to print in Vietnam but we may print and ship from the UK for some orders. 
Any additional funds raised will be used to commission more original art/ illustration for the zine. These won't be listed as stretch goals, but if the campaign is successful we will keep you updated regularly.
If we are satisfied with the amount of art in the zine and still have funds remaining, we will use this to recruit the services of a high profile professional RPG editor to give an extra layer of polish. We would love to include a professional editor from the outset, but our priority is to get as much high quality art into the zine as we can afford!
THE TEAM
Abigail Lingford - illustration 
Hoang Minh Nhat (Felicia) - playtesting, illustration and layout 
Jef Cox - illustration
Sofinho (Joey) - playtesting, writing and additional layout
Nguyen Thi Phuong Dzung - playtesting, spreadsheets (!) and additional layout
FINALLY...
We hope you can help us make issue one of Pariah a reality. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask them here or two contact me or on twitter: https://twitter.com/alonelabyrinth
...or email labyrinth.alone@gmail.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first kickstarter. I've done thorough research and augmented this with the publicly available advice of Zeshio, Zach from Soul Muppet, and Skerples (Coins and Scrolls) and am 100% certain I can do this with the support of my excellent collaborators. However, I am leading this project and if something DID happen to me it would slow it down a great deal.

The project is written in its entirety but could do with trimming down. Currently, this edit is something i am doing myself. If sufficient backing is achieved, I have approached a well-known professional RPG editor who will be on board. Even if we do not exceed our funding goal by enough to bring them in, I am still confident I can bring the word count down.

One can never anticipate events, and it is possible that hold-ups could occur at the printing end of things. I believe I've factored this into the delivery date (for the print edition) of August of this year. All being well, we should be able to get stuff sent out before then. 

I'm really excited to be getting this project off the ground. Publishing my own RPG has been a dream of mine since childhood and I will move heaven and earth to make it a reality. With the illustrators and other support I have, I truly believe we can make something special. The missing piece of the puzzle is you!

campaign.story:
The climate is changing, causing droughts and famines. Natural disasters limit the ability of governments to respond, and those governments are involved in wars that are bankrupting them. The global trade network has collapsed. And all this has created waves of migration, which governments are characterizing as ravening hordes, coming to destroy civilization.
Welcome to the Late Bronze Age Collapse.
It’s the turn of the 11th century BCE in the Mediterranean. The kingdoms of the Achaean Greeks, the empire of the Hittites, the trade centre of Troy, and the powerful city-states that line the coast have fallen. Egypt faces ruin. The world, as you know it, is ending.
You are one of many who have fled your homeland, finding a community among those now known as the Sea Peoples. How will you survive as order and government collapse? How will you protect your community—your friends and your family—in these most unstable times? Will you ever find peace?
Sagas of the Sea Peoples is a tabletop roleplaying game set in the Late Bronze Age Collapse. The characters are leaders of the Sea Peoples, seeking better lives, struggling against innumerable enemies, and facing the fall of the civilizations in which they were born.
The Quickstart is available at Itch.io and at DriveThru RPG. It offers a glimpse of the mechanics and the setting/historical period, as well as providing an introductory adventure.
The book will include rules designed specifically for Sagas of the Sea Peoples, a discussion of the Late Bronze Age Collapse and the role of the Sea Peoples in that period, a review of the Sea Peoples themselves—who they were and where they went—and a bibliography of sources in case the reader would like to do some further research or is curious regarding the topic. 
The current Patreon-only version of Sagas of the Sea Peoples—which has not been independently edited and has minimal art—is 100 pages. The book produced through this Kickstarter will also likely be around 100 pages, though stretch goals might push that up to around 150 pages. It will have black and white illustrations for its interior, possibly with some colour stock art. 
$ 5,500 (CAD): If we are able to raise $5,500 or more, the book will include a chapter on the likely challenges migrants and newly arrived minority communities—like the Sea Peoples—could face. This will help to better situate the Sea Peoples and provide inspiration for the characters' adventures, as well as offer context for the whole project.
We would also be able to engage a second sensitivity editor, and Catherine Liao has been kind enough to agree to help with this project if we reach this goal.
$ 6,250 (CAD): If we are able to raise $6,250 or more, the book would also include some more black and white illustrations. 
Designer: Fraser Ronald is a Canadian roleplaying game enthusiast and designer who has successfully Kickstarted and delivered Centurion: Legionaries of Rome, Nefertiti Overdrive, and Sword's Edge.
Graphic Design: Todd Crapper (yes, you read that right) is a graphic designer and a two-time ENnie award winning game designer for Killshot: The Director’s Cut and High Plains Samurai: Legends. 
Editor: Scott Vandervalk is an associate editor for Aurealis magazine and a freelance editor whose projects include Embers of the Forgotten Kingdom, the Baby Bestiary books, Nefertiti Overdrive, Costume Fairy Adventures and Crucible.
Sensitivity Editor: Ben Scerri is a non-binary bisexual Maltese Australian tabletop  and video game producer, writer, designer, and community builder, living  in Melbourne, Australia. 
Stretch Goal Sensitivity Editor: Catherine Liao is a freelance sensitivity reader and historical fiction writer. They are currently pursuing a degree in archaeology. They will be joining this project if we are able to raise $5,500.
Developmental Consultant: Kate Bullock is a community and convention organizer, freelancer, safety editor and consultant, and game designer. She's the President of the IGDN, game room organizer for Magpie Games, and one of the main people behind Breakout Gaming Convention. You can check out her work at http://bluestockings.ca.
Artists: Artists who will be creating the images for Sagas of the Sea Peoples include:
Laura Chisbert (also known as Laudrawin) is a self-taught digital artist from Spain. She aims to work as a concept artist (or any kind of artist, actually) in video game development. You can find her on Twitter.
Kim Hu is an illustrator and concept artist with a fondness for soda pops and skeletons.
Jennifer Ryan Kelly is an Irish artist who creates and illustrates, and also animates. Her genre of choice is fantasy and she loves to  experiment creatively. You can follow her on Instagram, Twitter, or support her on Patreon.
Kieron O’Gorman is an illustrator working in Ottawa who has created illustrations for game publishers Catalyst Game Labs, Pinnacle Entertainment, Rio Grande Games, Broken Ruler Games, Sword’s Edge Publishing, and others. You can find Kieron on Facebook.
Eric Quigley is a 33 year old freelance illustrator living in Portland with his  beautiful wife and cat.  His clients  include Monte Cook Games, DWD Studios, Inkwell Ideas, Hero Forge Games  (Hero Kids), and Michael Anderle's Kurtherian Gambit crew. 
Mars Skiff is a freelance fantasy illustrator and traditional painter based in  Washington state. They enjoy working in both digital and traditional  mediums, creating fantastical characters and settings. You can find Mars on Twitter.
Yung Yang started her career early when, at the tender age of 10, she sold a  sketch to a kind patron for the total sum of $5 and a stick of graphite.  She lives in California with her judgmental german shepherd and even more  judgmental horror movie collection.
I have published other games which might be of interest to those backing Sagas of the Sea Peoples. The PDFs of select games are available to backers at the Shekelesh level (20 CAD) and above.

updates.update_content:
Just after Sagas of the Sea Peoples failed to fund, a few people made mention of hoping I might revive the project in the future. An honest answer is in order, and I’m afraid that honest answer is: unlikely.
To flesh that out, I have no plans right now to undertake anything further. There's a chance I'll apply some of that knowledge to an adventure or series of adventures, but I don't think I'm the person to take on the story of the Sea Peoples and what their plight says about our present conditions. Without a lot of help, I'm not going to be able to do it justice. While I know that a large part of the Kickstarter failure was getting the word out, marketing is a nebulous science and I don't have the resources to hire someone to help with that, especially since it does not come with a guarantee of success.

I've been assigned a temporary duty in my day job that will require me to be travelling over the weekend, meaning I won't be able to respond when we learn the ultimate fate of Sagas of the Sea Peoples on Saturday, February 29. I will be in touch as soon as I am able.
Fingers crossed!

campaign.story:
You are exploring a tomb in search of a mirror fabled to foretell the future. You discover the tomb is inhabited by an undead queen and her spectral knights. In your exploration you have learned that she was murdered by the patriarchal structures of her own holy order. The method of her execution has denied her eternal rest. She plans murderous vengeance against the living but offers mercy under two conditions. First, help install her as an eternal monarch upon the religious throne. Second, eradicate the bloodline of those who betrayed her. What do you do? 
Dungeons & Dilemmas is a collection of system agnostic techniques for designing dungeon-based adventures that engage the players on an emotional and ethical level. The presented process approaches dungeons as their own unique narrative structure, and the encounters within them as moral puzzles.
Dungeons & Dilemmas treats deeper emotional engagement as an additive dimension of play on top of the exploration, hazard avoidance, monster fighting, and treasure collection elements of traditional fantasy adventure games. All the ideas, tools, and techniques presented speak to the strengths of existing rule systems in common use. GMs and players won't have to hand-wave away or house rule their games to accommodate this material.
For several years, I have been using these techniques to keep players emotionally engaged and ethically challenged with adventures that reach beyond the stereotype of "murder hobos" and excuses to just "kill things and take their stuff." #ZineQuest has provided a unique opportunity for me to share these ideas with you and hopefully help you think about the dungeon fantasy format in a slightly unique and fulfilling way.
Dungeons & Dilemmas is particularly well suited to games like: 
Torchbearer
Dungeon World
Any of the numerous OSR-style games such as  Old-School Essentials 
And, of course, the current edition of the most popular fantasy adventure game.
Project Structure
The current plan is a 5.5 x 8.5 saddle stitched booklet with black and white interior.  All illustrations will be pulled from creative commons or public domain sources.
Contents Overview
Building a Storied Dungeon Step-By-Step
Dungeon Layout as Narrative Pacing
Empty Rooms as Exposition
Traps as Foreshadowing
Magic Items as Ethical Challenges
Monsters as Remnants of Moral Failings
Villains as Justified Sinners
How to Stop Worrying About the Players Being Overpowered
Stretch Goals
$2000 Dungeons & Dilemmas will also include For the Love of Life and Death, a sample dungeon as an extended example of all the ideas working in concert.
Additional funds will be allocated to bringing on additional help such as a layout and graphic designer which will hopefully expedite the delivery process.
Schedule
March & April - Finish Writing (already well underway)
May & June - Editing and Layout
July & August - Printing and Delivery Logistics

campaign.story:
Hello! We would like to extend a big thanks to everyone who made this campaign a success. If you're here after the Kickstarter has ended but would like to get yourself a copy of the game, head over to  https://adamebell.itch.io/. We will be selling additional copies of the .pdf and zine there. We'll also have the community copies that were contributed by backers there where people can claim them. Thanks!
No Stone Unturned is a complete tabletop roleplaying game for 2-6 players. It's designed to play as a one-shot or short campaign, with sessions lasting from 2-4 hours each. Players will create characters and locations and take turns as the Arbiters of the world, meaning there is no set Game Master. 
You will create a story that features characters living in a world unrecognizable to our own. Their society is starting to pick up the pieces after yet another apocalypse. Natural catastrophes, manmade disasters, and external influences have caused collapse after collapse, but humanity has somehow hung on. Remainders of each of these civilizations and artifacts of their downfalls lurk hidden throughout the world.
Enough time has passed that many settlements have stabilized and are now looking to expand and explore what is around them. The characters that you will play live in one of these settlements and are tasked with exploring the world around them and acquiring what resources and knowledge that can be found. While that may sound like a noble cause, other societies, recovering wildlife, unstable ecosystems, and volatile remnants from disasters past are scattered all throughout the land. If these adventurers aren't careful, their actions will endanger their neighbors as well as their own homes…
No Stone Unturned is a complete game, with all of the rules needed to play contained inside the zine. All you need to play is the zine, character sheets, some notecards, and a handful of d4s, d6s, and d8s.
 Here is a high level overview of how you play the game:
Collaboratively design a world and a settlement for your characters to live in
Privately design other locations in the world and build out a map to explore
Create characters, and define their Moods, Aspects, Skills, and Sentiments
Adventure to one of the hidden location to try to find the things your settlement needs
Split the party! Act as Arbiter when your character is not in focus, performing duties relegated to the sole GM in other games
Trigger action rolls by endangering yourself or the world
Roll your character's current Mood vs the relevant Aspect. The winning side will add Details to change the fiction and show the results of your actions
When acting as Arbiter, mark the Collateral Clock when the characters act in a way that will leave a lasting impact
After the adventure, return home with whatever you found
Review the collateral clock of the location you just left and discuss the cumulative effect of your interference
Downtime! Rest, study what you found, recover harm, scout out the world, and consider plans to address the harm that you've caused. 
Go on another adventure, either by exploring a new location or revisiting an old one
The finished zine will be 54 printed pages bound with a red cardstock cover. Shipping to anywhere in the world is included in the zine-level pledge. Check out the samples below:
A sample spread from the worldbuilding section of the .pdf
A spread from our playtest copy that was printed at home
Cover of our playtest copy - the final cover will be printed on red cardstock
The two community copy models are there so that you can purchase copies that will be put up for free on itch.io. Both the digital copies will be available to be claimed for free by anybody without the means to purchase the game for themself.
 The full rules of the game are available to read over on the SRD for free. These will be updated with any edits to the text that may happen before the game goes fully to print. Feel free to check it out, share it, and play it from there!
We filmed a short 2 player playthrough of the game, which is broken into 3 parts for the main bits of the game: worldbuilding, and adventure, and downtime. The videos should give a good overview of what the game is like in play.
If the project funds well, we'd like to expand the scope of it a bit with these stretch goals:
(Unlocked) $500 - Funded!
(Unlocked) $600 - Adam will design and publish a working roll20 sheet for this game. He created the roll20 sheet for the rpg Mothership, so he has some experience in this area.
(Unlocked) $800 - Adam has a broad outline of a time travel hack, which he will begin ironing out the details of this and all backers will receive a free .pdf of the hack when it is complete. The pitch is that the players are time travelers who want to stop some great calamity. Instead of creating a world and settlement, you'll create a situation and a means of time travel. Then each player will author a different point in time that you'll need to travel to to try to prevent different precursors of the calamity from forming. Careful, though, too much interference and you'll break the whole dang world.
(Unlocked) $1000 - More art! We will add more art to the book and also the character sheet. There are a few pages right now that have white space between sections. Funding at this level will allow Sashah to create more art, or alternatively will allow us to commission some external artists.
Those are all the stretch goals we had in mind that are feasible right now. If we think of any more we'll add them!!  
 This game couldn't exist without the body of work put forth by the rest of the tabletop rpg community. The Ludography page of the SRD and .pdf features quite a few games that were direct inspirations. In particular, The Indie Hack by Slade Stolar laid out Hard, Scene, and Soft Details as featured in No Stone Unturned. This game runs on the Indie Hack Engine.
Adam and Sashah
Adam designed No Stone Unturned, and did the layout for the zine. It's been in development for about a year, after an early version of it fell out of his head into the first draft last March. Sashah edited and developed the text, and provided illustrations. They enjoyed drawing the flowers and birbs on this page and in the zine.
You can find Adam on most social media as @adamebell. Sashah can be found @zozo_q on Twitter. 
We recognize Kickstarter United
We want to express our support for Kickstarter staff, who are working to form a union. The success of this and so many Kickstarter projects is due in part to the hard work of the company’s employees, and we believe in their right to unionize.
At this time, union organizers are not calling for a boycott. Instead, they’re asking supporters to raise their voices and make our solidarity known.
  We call on Kickstarter’s senior leadership to recognize the union now, and we hope you’ll join me.
Solidarity forever 🤝

campaign.story:
We have all heard the stories of the Ulunak, the night sculptors. Their kingdom was a verdant paradise of vast rainforests surrounding the range of weathered mountain peaks, and surrounded by saltwater marshlands. Countless stories have been told about their great city of marble and glass, carved into the eponymous mountain. We have all enjoyed the Unani fruit cordials from their jungle plantations and the bitter herbs that grow in their marshland domain. We heard of their great soldiers, clad in woven reed and wielding blades of bronze.
The Queen of the Ulunaki was slain a palace coup last night, along with her royal consort, and most of her children. Only the Queen’s youngest daughter was rescued from the massacre by unlikely hands. These unseemly folk bore the Heir to her aunt Baru who could offer refuge to the rightful queen of Ulunak. The Heir recounted the story of their escape to Aunt Baru, who listened with rapt attention. It wasn't until the end of their story that she let on about her suspicions…

This is a tabletop roleplaying game about the future queen of Ulunak, and the unusual figures who came together to escort her to safety. This is a game for 3-6 players which takes place over a single session of 3-4 hours. 
Most of you will portray the Bearers, skillful and flawed adults who have chosen to escort the Heir to safety. You are a master of one of the six essential domains of the world; Warfare, Society, Sorcery, Religion, Nature, or Crime. To prove your value to the Heir and keep her safe, it is your job to warn of any dangers stemming from your domain. The Veteran may warn the group about an incoming patrol of soldiers, while the Shadow would point out that the kind guide is actually a con-artist. Bearers may also address threats, but doing so on your own Domain is likely to frighten the Heir. As a Bearer, your primary objective is to earn the Heir’s trust as you carry her to the safety of the aunt’s palace.
One of your number will play the Heir, daughter of the queen and the rightful ruler of the kingdom. The Heir is an innocent, compassionate young princess who has only seen a dozen winters. As the Heir, you facilitate the game and explain the rules. While you are but a young girl, each of her companions respects your potential as a leader and your word is final if ever a conflict arises. As the Heir, you watch your companions to judge if you trust or fear them. At the end of the game, Aunt Baru allows the Heir to decide the fates of each of the Bearers.
Palanquin is a game about a perilous journey and people trying to overcome their past. It’s inspired by classic indie roleplaying games such as…
 Dream Askew / Dream Apart, where players own certain elements of the fiction. 
 Kagematsu, where one person judges the behaviour of the many. 
 Witch: Road to Lindisfarne, centered on a perilous journey, where you discover the pasts of the travelers. 

Inspired by titles like Judges Guild, Alarums & Excursions, and A Pound of Flesh, Kickstarter is inviting creators to launch two-week campaigns for their own RPG-inspired zines as part of Zinequest 2. Palanquin is one such product, designed to give a complete, memorable story in a small package. The campaign has a low goal and is only running for two weeks, so spread the word!
Zine Quest 2!
Palanquin is a 36-page black and white saddle-stitched zine. The best way to play is for each player to have their own copy of the zine double as character sheets. No prep, just play!
If you want to decide on your reward level, here’s what you need to know.
 Bearer of Whispers: PDF only, great as a print and play.
 Bearer of Dreams: Discount print copy for folks from marginalized backgrounds or experiencing poverty.
 Bearer of Wisdom:  Standard print copy of the game  along with a PDF.
 Bearer of Futures: Six print copies of the zine along with the PDFs, so no print-outs are needed.
 Bearer of Hope: Five standard print copies of the zine, and a single full-colour, hand-sewn deluxe copy.
Images of the Digital, Standard, and Deluxe covers.

For every 10 backers for the kickstarter, we will unlock another community copy for folks in need. 
Retailer Note: Traditional zines are often not retail-friendly, but we will be happy to get you copies of the game if you are interested. Just contact us at genesisoflegend@gmail.com

This small game has been made possible thanks to…
Jason Pitre is the writer, game designer, and graphic designer of Palanquin. You may know him as the designer behind the Spark Roleplaying Game, Posthuman Pathways, Sig: Manual of the Primes. and After the War. Check him out at http://www.genesisoflegend.com/
Lauren McManamon is our extraordinary editor on the project who you might know from her amazing zinequest game, Girl Underground. She has a number of editing credits for games including Good Society and the Great American Novel. Check out her work at https://www.thestraykiwi.com
Mia Minnis is our lead artist for the project, who works as a freelance illustrator and concept designer in Richmond, VA. She's been doing illustration and concept design her whole life and enjoys nothing like a good book, fantasy rpg, and girls with complex moral motivations holding knives. Check out her work at https://www.miaminnis.com
Avery Alder provided consultation on the project which greatly helped the information design of the project. Avery’s work blends facilitation, design, and play – bringing keen curiosity and visionary imagination to how we create together. Check out her work at https://buriedwithoutceremony.com/
Zinequest is a celebration of creativity and art in roleplaying games. We wanted to take a chance to share links to other Zinequest campaigns past and present for you to enjoy. Share the love!
ZineQuest 1
 Girl Underground is the inspiration for Palanquin. This is a tabletop RPG about a curious girl in a wondrous world, for telling stories like Alice in Wonderland or The Wizard of Oz. It was co-designed by our fantastic editor Lauren McManamon  and Jesse Ross.  
 The Goblinville Gazetteis a roleplaying game about broke goblins and the town they live in. 
 Cats & Cats: Cat cat catcat cat catly cats
 The Demon Collective: Vol 1 is a zine of 4 horror RPG adventures, written, illustrated, and edited by trans and nonbinary gamers. 
 The RPG Design Zine is a brilliant cut-and-paste zine about game design by Nathan D. Paoletta. 

ZineQuest 2
In addition to Palanquin, you may be interested in some of these other campagns that are currently running during Zinequest 2 in 2020. Share the love!
The Artefact is a solo RPG zine where you craft a unique magical item and play to find out how it changes as it passes through the hands of many different keepers.
No Stone Unturned is a tabletop RPG where players collectively build a post-apocalyptic world and explore it together.
A Touch of Glamour isa game of fey mayhem, as Powered by the Apocalypse.
Beak, Feather, & Bone is a competitive map-labeling RPG and worldbuilding tool.
The Great Soul Train Robbery is a one-shot tabletop rpg about Desperados robbing the train to Hell.
Not Pretty but Wonderfulis a series of conversations with game designers captured in zine format. 
Dish Pit Witches is a small RPG zine about gay witches who work in a restaurant. 
Dungeons & Dilemmas is a Zinequest RPG Toolkit for designing dungeons as a narrative framework and encounters as moral puzzles.
The Necronomizine  is a zine of small, eldritch horror game scenarios and content.
Lost Roads is a tabletop RPG about climate migration in a bygone age.  We destroyed our world with magic unchecked, and try to nurture a rebirth.
Ever In Her Sights is a game about Knights, set out to retrieve treasures for their High Queen.What will you claim? What will you sacrifice?
A Fine Mess is a narrative heist game where reality is malleable, with a mix of Cortex Plus Action and Blades in the Dark. 
Mage Against the Machine may have the best title I have seen. It's a tabletop RPG about time-traveling wizards risking it all to stop the robot apocalypse.
Space Seeds is a small zine full of encounters and adventure seeds for use with most science fiction rpgs.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The game is completely designed, written, edited, and laid-out. We are just doing the finishing touches on a couple pieces of art and we will be ready to physically print and ship out these games. We have also delivered multiple projects in the past, which has taught us about some of the risks associated with projects.

Following the ideals of zine-quest, we aim for simplicity. We can produce limited quantities of the zine at our headquarters, or hire a local print shop to produce more of them. The base goal is all we need to succeed, and there are no stretch goals.

updates.update_content:
Hello everyone,
I hope that all of you fine folks are safe and healthy in this challenging time. I wanted to let you know that I have officially sent out 283 letters and parcels containing rewards to backers of this kickstarter campaign. Nearly all of the rewards are now in the mail system and I expect that most of you will receive your copies in the coming weeks. I am eager to hear your thoughts!

Hello everyone,
It has been a very eventful couple weeks since our last update, and I wanted to give you a status update on the project. The current COVID-19 pandemic has certainly complicated the fulfillment process, but I am very glad to report that we received 500 copies of the standard, black & white zine from the local print shop a couple days before a local lockdown shut all businesses in the area. Have a look!

Hello everyone!
Last week, I pressed sent out digital copies of Palanquin to backers and began the proofing process with a local printer for the physical copies of the zine. A couple keen-eyed backers noticed that something was amiss  with a few pages of the document. It turns out that in my enthusiasm, I had uploaded an older version of the PDF and allowed a rather foolish copy-paste error in the Shadow Bearer description to propagate. I want to thank a number of kind backers for contacting me about the issues early enough that I could make the relevant corrections. This also means that…

461 backers raised over $6,000 Canadian in order to make Palanquin a success. We managed such a feat thanks to your collective passion and generosity of spirit. I am blown away at how this has turned out and will do my best to get the game to you shortly. 
I am currently just waiting on the final pieces of art, and then the printing/manufacturing process shall begin. I will be using a local print shop for the majority of the copies, and will hand assemble the remaining ones. I will be fulfilling all of this through the normal mail service so there won't be tracking available, but it will be relatively fast.

Hello everyone! 
The enthusiasm for this campaign is infectious and I am so very happy that you have decided to come along for the ride. I just wanted to let you folks know that we have a bit over 36 hours left in the campaign for the Palanquin RPG. We won't have a pledge manager this time, so I would encourage you to make any adjustments in the next day and a half. 
If you are at the digital level, feel free to grab a physical copy of the zine at the Bearer of Wisdom level if you would like. The shipping is quite affordable due to the size of the publication.

Hello Everyone!
It’s been two days since the campaign for Palanquin launched, and I am stunned at how enthusiastic you fine folks are about this little game. So far, we have had over a 180 backers join us on this perilous journey, and I certainly feel like you folks have earned my trust.
As I mentioned in the “Risks and challenges” section, we don’t intend on any stretch goals for this project. That said, I have gotten a number of requests for additional colour copies of the zine. That’s why I have added a new pledge level called “” for $18 CAD.  If you back at this level, you will get a single physical copy of the Zine in full colour, staple-bound.

campaign.story:
Help fund the next two years of Canada's only SFWA  (Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America) recognized professional magazine. Augur Magazine strives to create a compassionate, critical, and creative space while publishing fantastic works of literature.
In our first two years, we've gone from paying $0.02/word (CAD) to $0.11/word—growth we never could have imaged. With you as our backer, we'll keep growing. Help us to continue breaking down the boundary between literary and speculative fictions, so we can keep creating opportunities for creators around the world.
In Ancient Rome, an Augur foretold futures by watching the flight patterns of birds.
In Toronto, today, Augur Magazine believes the stories we tell now have a direct impact on the futures we're creating.
Our mission statement is to find "stories for the futures we need". To support this mission, we've developed three key pillars: first, we muddy the line between literary and speculative fiction by publishing uncanny realism alongside classic scifi-fantasy; second, we carefully and respectfully choose the pieces that represent our publication in a process informed by empathy; and, finally, we aspire to lift up under-represented and marginalized voices as often as we can.
Augur Magazine strives to create a compassionate, critical, and creative literary space—while publishing fantastic works of literature. It is currently the only SFWA-recognized pro market in Canada, and we intend to use that status to create more opportunities for Canadian, Indigenous, and worldwide creators. We are an all-volunteer team that donates thousands of hours per year to our community and, if funded, we can't wait to continue that work.
We itching to keep looking for the stories that inform the type of world we want to live in, whether dreamy realism, fabulism, science fiction, fantasy, slipstream, horror, fairy tale, myth, steampunk, apocalyptic, or any other genre.
Because we want all of them. And everything in between. 
 Like many projects, Augur Magazine was conceived in a basement, back in the summer of 2016. After months of planning, it was launched with a call for submissions for its first project: the Augur Magazine Preview Issue, a collection of reprints that would set the tone for what Augur would publish. More than five hundred submissions later, the Preview Issue launched the same day as Augur's first Kickstarter.
By the end of September 2017, Augur was funded for its first two years—paying just $0.02/word at the time.
Since 2017, the team has had an incredible time working with creators and getting involved in both Canadian and speculative fiction literary communities. We've been overwhelmed by the response to our work, including:
Receiving more than 7000 submissions since we opened in 2017
Publishing 65+ creators over 7 issues
Growing to a team of 25+ volunteers
Being reviewed by Quick Sip Reviews, Maria Haskins, and Locus Magazine
Making the Locus and Nebula Recommended Reading Lists
Having a story on the Sunburst Awards Longlist
Publishing 55+ blog posts
Receiving funding from the Ontario Arts Council to support our creators and boost our rates from $0.02/word to $0.06/word
Receiving funding from the Toronto Arts Council to create our inaugural conference, Augury
Becoming an official incorporated nonprofit organization
Supporting a reading series to celebrate speculative fiction monthly in Toronto
Representing Augur at programming at CanCon, the Toronto Public Library, the University of Toronto, and the Toronto International Festival of Authors
Raising our rates again from $0.06/word to $0.11/word...and becoming a qualifying, SFWA recognized pro paying market starting with pieces published in Issue 3.1
Sometimes, it seems like too much to imagine it all taking place in the last two years. Our team is so thankful that we've had the opportunity to have these experiences, to work with our wonderful contributors, and to support Augur in growing past what we ever imagined during those first meetings in 2016. 
Augur Covers, Issue 1.1-2.3
What's next? 2020 is a huge year for Augur. This year, we're publishing our first SFWA-qualifying issues. We're reducing the number of issues from three to two, but keeping roughly the same number of published creators. With your help, we hope to add even more slots than previous years. If we break past our goal of $12,000, we'll add more opportunities than ever before for writers to be published in our digital pages.
But our first Kickstarter was only built to cover 2018 and 2019.
If we want to see as much growth in the next two years as we've created in our first two, we'll need your support.
 If funded, Augur Magazine will be ready to go for Years 3 and 4. That's four new issues of work, meaning at least 16+ stories, 24+ poems, and 4 comics. Our rates will be maintained at their current pro-paying status of $0.11/word (CAD, and assume CAD for all $) for fiction, $60/poem and $50/page for comics. We'll also continue doing our community work as the Augur Magazine Literary Society, including our upcoming partnership with the Ephemera Reading Series and our 2020 conference, Augury (although these projects have different funding behind them).
That's where we'll get with $12,000 CAD. If we go past it? Here's what you can look forward to:
 $13,500.00 // Poetry Boost - Augur will publish four more poems per year. That's eight poems we wouldn't publish otherwise, bringing our total up to 32 new poems from 2020-2021.
 $15,000.00 // Comics Boost - Augur will boost comics pay from $50/page to $70/page, putting more money in our comic artists' pockets.
 $16,500.00 // Fiction Boost - We'll add 6,000 words of prose per year. That's 12,000 words total, bringing our total number of stories up to 20-24.
 $19,000.00 // Print Edition - We'll print a collected volume of Augur's Issues 2.1-2.3 and send it to every Lifetime Subscriber who's contributed $100 or more.
 $21,000.00 // Reprint Boost - Our blog will publish 1 reprint every month, paying $20-40 per reprint.
 $24,000.00 // Small Press Boost - You ready for it? Augur opens a small press. We'll start purchasing and printing short fiction (Novella) and poetry books. That's right. Longer short fiction, curated by the Augur team, at your fingertips. We're ready—are you?
 A kickstarter is only as good as its rewards. So here are some of the rewards you can look forward to:
Single issues of the Augur Preview Issue, Issue 1.1, and/or Issue 3.1 
 Digital Augurian Badge, so you can show off that you've backed us with Augurian pride
 1-, 2-, and 5-Year Subscriptions so you can keep up with all our latest publications (including early bird deals!)
 Lifetime subscriptions, including every issue that Augur has published up until now
Recognition on the Augur Kickstarter acknowledgement page at the back of every issue
Working with an Augur artist on a custom illustration of your choice
Receiving an edit of up to 6000 words from an Augurian staff member, or past Augur contributors like A.C. Wise, Kate Heartfield, or Michael Matheson 
Getting a comic of up to 10 pages edited by Augur Comics Editor Amy Wang 
Having your chapbook-length project reviewed by Augur Poetry Editor Terese Mason Pierre 
Working directly with an Augur staff member on a Novella-length project edit 
 Spending an hour, digitally or in person in Toronto, with Augur Publisher Kerrie Seljak-Byrne and Editor in Chief Alex De Pompa, to chat publishing, writing, editing, and anything speculative or literary—and they'll even send you Toronto coffee beans if you're meeting from afar!
Augur swag available at select levels
And then, of course, there's the swag available at select levels, including:
 Full-length books by Augurian creators Dominik Parisien, Lina Rather, Kate Heartfield, and/or Andrew Wilmot
Limited edition print copies of Augur Magazine Issue 1.3
 Postcards and bookmarks featuring Augur art
A wooden feather pin 
An Augur cover art print on textured paper
An Augur tote bag featuring our mission statement: "Stories for the Futures We Need"
A custom canvas painting by Augur illustrator Ann Sheng in the series of pieces she did featuring Canadian landscapes with speculative elements
-----------------------------------------
And that's everything. If you have questions, reach out to us on Twitter at @augurmag.
Otherwise...thank you, from our team to you, for spending the time reading through our campaign. We're so excited to make Augur 2020-2021 happen.
Sincerely,
Kerrie Seljak-Byrne, Publisher / Alex De Pompa, Editor in Chief / Lawrence Stewen, Managing Editor / Terese Mason Pierre, Poetry Editor / Amy Wang, Comics Editor / Anna Bendiy, Managing Blog Editor / Victoria Liao, Editor / Vivian Li, Assistant Editor
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We're an all-volunteer team, and when the team shifts and changes that means that timelines can sometimes change as well. We've done our best to split work across the team and set up our production schedule to take these changes into account. Issue 3.1 is slated to come out in June 2020, and all rewards will be sent out by the time we launch (with the exception of editorial projects with timelines decided with the writer's project availability).

updates.update_content:
Hi there, Augurians.
When we wrapped this campaign, it felt like a moment of wonderful glory. We’re so thankful for you, your contributions, and your support.
As a team, we took the first 2-3 weeks off after the Kickstarter, intending to evaluate where we were, how to get all our balls rolling, and what to get started first.

updates.update_userinfo: Final Countdown: A Note From the Publisher
updates.update_content:
I'll keep this brief.
Here's the deal: we've passed 150% funded. That's $18,000.
$18,000 raised for our magazine in 28 days. Our community donated an average of $643 per day. Which is so, so beyond our expectations.
When we launched this campaign, we were ready for the long haul. Our first Kickstarter wasn't easy. We funded at the end of our 3rd week. At the time, we were funding for $6,000. Half of what we needed this time. Honestly, we weren't sure we would even make it this year.

updates.update_userinfo: Making Inclusivity More Than a Buzzword: A Note from Natasha Ramoutar
updates.update_content:
Augurians, as of now we only have 39 hours left!
With less than two full days until the end of our campaign, the Augur team is ready to go all out for our final hours. We want to see how much support we can gather, and how many more goals we'll hit, before time runs out.
If you've been waiting to share or back our campaign, then there's no better time than now. Together, we'll be able to give our campaign the final push it needs to take it beyond all our expectations!

updates.update_userinfo: Realism Shattered: Finding Hope and Healing in the Futures We Need
updates.update_content:
Good morning Augurians!
We’re fast approaching the end of this campaign, and what a whirlwind it’s been. As of the time of posting this, there are just 60 hours left for our Kickstarter! If you've been meaning to share our campaign but haven't had the chance to yet, this is the perfect time to help us reach even more people before the end of the month. 
Today’s update is our final personal essay, and is the second essay from our Managing Editor Lawrence Stewen. It’s no secret that speculative literature is often seen as “less than” realist literature, and that many enforce a rigid boundary between the two. For Lawrence, this line of thought is more unhelpful and inaccurate than ever. In today’s fractured world, speculative literature offers an exciting vehicle to represent and interpret our realities, and can provide us with the tools needed to construct new stories.

updates.update_userinfo: What Publishing Compassionately Means to Augur
updates.update_content:
Here we go, Augurians: the final three days!
This campaign has been a wild ride of fun, joy, and bewilderment for us, and we’re so happy to have you with us every step of the way.
In today’s update, our Publisher Kerrie Seljak-Byrne explores what publishing compassionately means to Augur, and what concrete steps we can take to make this space as equitable and responsive as possible. There will always be room for improvement. But as Kerrie says, for as long as Augur exists, “we will do our best to always stand by, for, and with our community”.

updates.update_userinfo: The Author’s Vision Comes First: Augur’s Editorial Process
updates.update_content:
Good afternoon Augurians! 
If you haven't heard yet, yesterday we passed $16,500 and hit our third stretch goal!! That's right, we're adding 12,000 more words of fiction to Augur Years 3+4! 
Our first three stretch goals were all about boosting Augur Magazine. Thanks to your support, we'll be publishing 2 more poems and 1-2 more stories each issue, as well as paying our comics creators up to $420 for 6 pages. This means that future issues of Augur We are so excited to bring you even more amazing work over the next two years, and we can't thank you enough for making this happen!

updates.update_userinfo: The Limits of Empathy: Centering Own-Voices Narratives at All Levels of the Creative Process
updates.update_content:
Good morning! On this bright Monday we have 334 backers and just 5 days left for our Kickstarter! Not to mention that we only need $363 to hit our next stretch goal! After that, let's hit the rest of them before we're done!
In today's update,  Augur's Graphic-Fiction Editor, Amy Wang, talks about the issue of writing a story from another's perspective. This problem is most commonly encountered when white male writers create stories with characters, themes, or settings that they have not directly experienced—and so require the input of marginalized folk to ensure that their end-product is "empathetic" to the lives they are pulling from.

updates.update_userinfo: Foolishness: A Meditation on Impostor Syndrome
updates.update_content:
Hello Augurians! We hope you are all having a great Sunday!
We are at our last 6 days of running our Kickstarter! Time went by so fast! As of now, we are at 329 backers, and $652 away from our next stretch goal. We can almost taste that Fiction Boost! Hopefully, with your generous support, these final days will go beyond all of our expectations.
Today's update is a piece about self-doubt and imposter syndrome by Augur founder, and emeritus editor, Mado Christie. They recall two momentous, life-changing experiences where the nagging feeling of "not being qualified enough" haunted them in times when great responsibility and trust were placed on their shoulders.

Good Saturday morning! We hope your weekend is off to a great start!
It's certainly going well for us! We are now only $702 away from our Fiction Boost stretch goal and 328 backers strong. There's only 8 days left in the Kickstarter, and we want to reach as many goals as we can before time's up! 
With your help, we'll sprint through our Fiction Boost and right into our Print Editions goal, where we'll be able to print out physical editions of Augur Issues 2.1-2.3!
