campaign.story:
Venture and Dungeon are two tabletop roleplaying games inspired by traditional high fantasy rpgs like Dungeons & Dragons.
Venture is a game of introspective heroic fantasy. You play an adventuring party of a traditional fantasy story, but framed in a way that shifts your perspective, focusing on the inner lives of the characters. 
The game is written to encourage players and characters to think about who they are, what they are doing, and why they are doing it. What does it mean to be a Cleric with a personal relationship to a deity? How does it feel to create magic out of nothing as the Wizard? Venture is a game about understanding the archetype through the character, and understanding the character beyond their archetype.
If you want to play a game of Venture using an already existent D&D character or party, you can absolutely do that, and you'll create a totally different and interesting story than you could in D&D. If you want to create new characters in Venture, the character sheets give you the prompts and space to do just that.
Dungeon is a game about recapturing the experience of enjoying traditional fantasy narratives. You play a group of young kids playing Dungeons & Dragons while grappling with the perils of high school, and how these things can intersect.
In Dungeon, the characters the kids play are tied to the feelings and experiences of the kids themselves. The magic the characters can cast are reflections of the kids' own skills and experiences, and the monsters the kids face are allegorical to the challenges they experience in day-to-day life. Like all of Jay's work, Dungeon is a queer narrative that features genders tied up in high school experiences and a flexible approach to the ever-shifting teenage identity.
Dungeon is born from Jay's memories of being a young adult and loving Dungeons & Dragons, and now grappling with a more complicated relationship with the same game. It's both a love letter to D&D and an acknowledgement of why they had to move past it.
Both Venture and Dungeon are games of Belonging Outside Belonging, a tabletop roleplaying game system spearheaded by Dream Apart / Dream Askew by Avery Alder and Benjamin Rosenbaum. It uses no dice and has no GM; instead each player has a player character and have equal control over the story, using a token economy of strong and weak moves to advance the narrative. The BoB system creates stories of intimate communities and their interpersonal conflicts, struggles, and triumphs.  
How do you play?
In Venture and Dungeon, each player will pick a playbook that contains lists of traits to choose for your character. In Venture, you will choose two looks, a wardrobe style, and two things you are and two you are not. Additionally, each playbook has two additional questions that relate to their role specifically. In Dungeon, you will choose a name and gender for your kid, a name and look for your hero, and an additional playbook-specific choice.
The playbooks all also have moves, which you will use to exert agency in the story; strong moves cost tokens that you gain with weak moves.
The base game of Venture has six playbooks: The Bard, The Cleric, The Fighter, The Paladin, The Rogue, and The Wizard.
The base game of Dungeon has six playbooks: The Cleric, The Fighter, The Rogue, The Wizard, The Game Master, and The Kid.
The Fighter playbook from Venture (layout not final)
Cleric playbook for Dungeon (layout not final)
As a group, you will also make choices about setting elements, which are the environmental and societal forces that will interact with your characters. During the story, players may "pick up" setting elements and act as their embodiments in scenes where other characters are interacting with them. Setting elements are a way to build your world and introduce NPCs and ideas for your characters to interact and come into conflict with.
The base game of Venture has six setting elements: The Darkness, The Celestial, The Arcane, The Mundane, The Authority, and The Underbelly.
The base game of Dungeon has four setting elements: The Dungeon, The Mysteries, The Powers-That-Be, and The Denizens. It also features a rotating cast of Monster Elements, which includes (but is not limited to) The Undead Hordes, The Gazing Monstrosity, and The Great Dragon.
The Darkness and The Celestial setting elements from Venture (layout not final)
Dungeon setting element for Dungeon (layout not final)

The Designers
Riley Rethal is the designer of Venture. She is a 20 year old biology student who has spent the last three summers teaching kids roleplaying games as a summer camp counselor. She enjoys writing games that encourage collaboration and exploration.
Riley has written many games in the past year, such as The Riot Starts, a gmless game about revolution and community in the capitalist hell of the underworld, Ayekah, a two-player game about a Jewish relationship with god, and It's Been A Long, Long Time, a two-player game about a relationship that is separated and reunites. You can find all of those games and more at metagame.itch.io.
This is her fourth TTRPG Kickstarter, so she has some experience with this kind of thing. The first was Synthesis for Zinequest last year, an experimental zine with a collection of small games about meta and perspective. The second was for a print run of Dusk to Midnight, her #sadmechjam game about doomed soldiers in a losing war. And the third was co-organizing Doikayt, a Jewish TTRPG anthology that was successful beyond its contributors' wildest dreams.
Jay Dragon is the designer of Dungeon. They are a 22 year old vagabond who has spent much of their life teaching queer teenagers how to LARP in the Hudson Valley. They write games about gender, emotional experiences, shifting identities, community, and love.
Jay has been writing games since they were 14 years old, but only in the past year have they been publishing. Their first major release was Sleepaway, another Belonging Outside Belonging game, revolving around summer camp counselors protecting their kids from a monstrous Lindworm. They've also released Esoteric, a series of ritual games played in secret (I cannot tell you more than that), and Kid Impossible, a 1+ player game about being a teenage superhero, making friends, and fighting monsters. They also release a series of poetic zines called Games For The Missing & The Found, which they use to express their feelings about games and constantly redefine what precisely a game is.
This is their second RPG Kickstarter, with the first being Sleepaway, which succeeded admirably. They promise they don't just write games about teenagers going on adventures.
The Team
Ruby Lavin is the layout artist for Venture & Dungeon. She's a graphic designer and illustrator living in Philadelphia. She likes texture, critical theory, fantasy, and weird plants. You can find her graphic design portfolio here. 
Marn S is the editor for Venture & Dungeon. She is an author, library worker, and podcaster, who has been self-publishing her own writing and editing others’ since 2012. She currently writes and edits for her collaborative web serial Prairie Song, and edits for the Quoria web serial. You can find her short stories and TTRPGS here.
Worsey is the artist for Venture & Dungeon. She created the incredible cover photo. Worsey is a freelance illustrator and animator, with dreams of being a board artist. She loves LARP, TTRPGs and her two rats. You can contact her at worseyart[AT]gmail.com. 
What People Are Saying About Venture
"I love its determined insistent focus on the internal lives of the characters. the personhood of these fantasy archetypes. what does it *mean* to be a fighter, a wizard, a thief.   what do these ways of relating to this world reveal about your strengths, flaws, hopes, and dreams
it’s a game that reinvests curiosity & compassion back into the tired tropes of the “dungeon/adventure fantasy” genre.   what are the struggles of a paladin, driven by ideology and convinced they have a Purpose? what is it really like to have a personal relationship *with a god*?
this is a game about fantasy heroes struggling in a very human way with what it means to do good, to care for each other, to work through their failings, and to find purpose, while living in the shadow of the powerful existential and political forces that shape their world
[...] this is a powerful game.   even if you only play D&D, buy it. the lens it shines on character class & the questions it asks in one page will do more to help you build an interesting character than the entire Players Handbook  this is the Marxist heroic fantasy game we all deserve" – Luke Jordan, designer of Heaven in the Dust
"venture takes everything you love about dungeon world and other fantasy games, removes the GM, and sets you loose to go hog wild. others are saying more exciting and deeper things about it but i fell in love with this game from the first time i saw the paladin moves... same with the celestial setting element... and y'all should be buying this and playing it." – a. fell, designer of Memoria
"yeah yeah yeah YEAH YEAH YEAH" – Tom Parkinson-Morgan, co-designer of Lancer
What People Are Saying About Dungeon
“heartfelt, relatable, and insightful, dungeon is a brilliant game. it takes familiar tropes - the trappings of dungeon fantasy, socially-awkward children playing D&D as an escape from their lives - and deftly stitches them together into one beautifully-cohesive whole.
It offers a unique perspective onto both dungeon fantasy at large and the relationship between players, their characters, and the reasons we play. and all with a keenly-observant eye for detail and the compassion and respect for the humanity and rich interiority of children that characterises Jay’s work about young people.” – Luke Jordan, designer of Heaven in the Dust
"Dungeon is a game that wears what it's about with pride. It's about D&D, sure, but more than that it's about the relationships we have with things that were close to us when we were young. The way the playbooks and tools are built instill a feeling of playing RPGs while concretely establishing themes about the interpersonal and connections with games." – Nevyn Holmes, designer of Skel-IT-ons and creator of IndieBytes
"this game rules and i would be saying that even if i wasn't also getting money from this kickstarter" – Riley Rethal, designer of Venture
Backer Tiers
There are many different options to choose from for your adventure:
 The PDF ($15): get the PDF of the book, fulfilled by itch.io!
 PDF + Donation ($24): get the PDF, and donate a community copy PDF for someone who can't afford the game! These will be able to be claimed on the itch.io page when it is published.
 The Book ($25): get a physical book and the PDF!
 Book + Donation ($34): get a physical book, PDF, and donate a community copy PDF!
 2 Books ($46): get two copies of the book, plus a PDF. Perfect for you and a friend.
 Keeper Dedication ($100): get a special, one of a kind dedication in the zine as a "Keeper" of a setting element. You will also of course receive a book and PDF. This is an exclusive tier, with only one dedication available per setting element. Setting elements still available: (Venture) The Authority. (Dungeon) The Dungeon, The Powers-That-Be, The Denizens.
 Friend Dedication ($150): get a special, one of a kind dedication in the zine as a "Friend" of a playbook. You will also of course receive a book and PDF. This is an exclusive tier, with only one dedication available per playbook. Playbooks still available: (Venture) The Cleric, The Fighter, The Paladin. (Dungeon) The Cleric, The Fighter, The Kid, The Rogue, The Wizard.
Where does the money go?
 $1,000: design compensation for the two of us.
 $500: cover & interior art.
 $500: layout.
 $360: printing the books, via Mixam.
 $350: shipping the books out to all of you.
 $300: editing.
 $350 for kickstarter fees and $140 as a buffer.
Stretch Goals!
FUNDED! at $4,000 we will get an additional Venture playbook: The Druid by Luke Jordan of Wildwood Games. Luke is a prolific writer of Belonging Outside Belonging games, including Heaven in the Dust (one of my favorite games ever), Heaven Has No Taste, and Dream Anew. They are a fantastic designer and their already in-progress Druid playbook is a wonderful exploration of the impulse towards isolation.
FUNDED! at $4,500 we will get two additional Monsters for Dungeon: 
 The Glamorous Ones by Caro Asercion. Their culture is arcane, inscrutable, and esoteric. They lord their power over others, and speak in riddles of worlds beyond your understanding. They are beautiful, fickle, and far, far older than you. Are they supernatural? Or just college students?
 The Vampire by Luke Jordan of Wildwood Games. There’s a monster in human skin who walks the halls of your High School. Everyone knows it, but no-one dares to do anything. Cold and cruel and beautiful, they rule over the rabble around them with an iron fist and a silver tongue, and feed on the misery and drama they cause.
FUNDED! at $5,000 everyone working on the book will get a pay boost!
FUNDED! at $5,500 we will commission more art for the book.
FUNDED! at $6,000 we will get an additional Venture playbook: The Immolator by a. fell, aka Kales. Kales is an amazing writer and game designer, as well as a player on the Follow the Leader podcast. Their already in-progress Immolator playbook is a beautiful exploration of sacrifice and passion.
FUNDED! at $6,500 we will get two additional Monsters for Dungeon:
 The Giant by Eric Mersmann. there's a presence looming over you, the weight of it forcing you to be like it: strong, feared, resilient, violent. Be a giant or be crushed.
 The Homunculi by Abe Mendes. At High School, you accumulate numbers and letters that aim to define you in absolutes. They combine to form a two-dimensional facsimile of yourself, unambiguously good or bad or smart or lazy, that follows you through the halls and claims to control your fate.
FUNDED! at $7,000 everyone working on the book will get a pay boost!
FUNDED! at $7,500 we will commission more art for the book.
FUNDED! at $8,000 we will get an additional Venture playbook: The Warlock by Atlas. Atlas is the other co-designer of Heaven Has No Taste, and also my birthday twin. His already in-progress Warlock playbook will explore deviant identity and self-expression.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone, it's Jay here!  This is just an update to reassure everyone that yes, we're still here and we're still working on the game. I've gotten some messages from backers asking about delays and with some questions about how the project is going, so I just wanted to address all that now.  
Why is the project late?  
As I mentioned in the last update, this project was started at the beginning of February. Please imagine going back to yourself back then, before quarantine, before all of 2020, and having the same priorities that you do now. And now extend that, not only to Riley and myself, but also to all of our team. It's very hard to ask a stretch goal writer to prioritize a bit of writing over stuff like "finding a place to sleep" or "surviving the month." I know most of us have adapted to this new normal by now, but things are still really hard across the board.  I refuse to destroy the mental and physical wellbeing of my coworkers and colleagues in order to get all of you your elf game faster. That leads to worse work and is, simply, morally wrong. There are areas where the project has been lagging, but we're taking steps to handle that that won't require crunching anyone.

Hi everyone!
Well, it's November—it's sure been a long, long 2020. We started this project back in February, which feels like both a thousand years and a couple minutes ago. This project started at a very different point in our lives, one where we didn't really have an idea of what was coming next. Because of this (among other reasons) our lovely book is taking a bit of time to reach the finish line. We're aware that our October ship date came and went, and we're sorry for the radio silence over here. My goal is always to make sure all of you are on board and aware of the process that's happening, and I'm really grateful for your patience and care.

Good afternoon, everyone.
We are currently deep in the midst of a global pandemic. While this is affecting everyone in very different ways, it is also undeniably tied to a surge in mental health struggles, and the isolation, quarantine, and shift to online classes and work has poorly impacted many people. Because of this, Riley and myself have been putting Venture & Dungeon on the backburner for the moment, as we prioritize our own health and the health of our communities. We are still having meetings about the project, and making important steps behind the scenes to get things done, although we don't have anything flashy to show off yet. While we are experiencing delays in our own schedules, we anticipate no delays in the release of the book itself at the anticipated time.

Hey everyone!
One week ago today, the Venture & Dungeon kickstarter campaign ended at over $17,000—almost 500% of our original goal! That's absolutely incredible, Jay and I cannot thank you enough. 
Everyone involved in the project is already hard at work to get the books out to all of you—Jay and I had a talk yesterday about (finally) writing up instructions for the games and I am very excited about the way we're planning to build on and adapt the BoB system based on our experience playing these games.

Hey everyone! 
We're still chugging along meeting stretch goals; yesterday we unlocked Jeeyon's Ranger playbook, which I am so excited to see! Next one up is $13k, which would bring up our contributors' pay to double what was originally budgeted, so that's very exciting!
Jay and I have also been talking to Worsey, our artist, about what we want the art for the book to look like, and now I'm even more psyched about it than I was before. She's been sketching Dungeon characters, and they're so good and adorable!! Look at them!!

Hey everyone,
Recently, we reached $10k, which is absolutely amazing!! Jay and I cannot thank you enough for your support! You may have noticed that this means we've cleared all the stretch goals we had planned, but worry not! We've got a few more up our sleeve. 
at $11,000 everyone working on the project will get a pay boost!
at $12,000 we will get an additional Venture playbook: The Ranger by Jeeyon Shim. Jeeyon is an amazing designer who focuses on connection with the natural world in both her games and the rest of her life, so she is the perfect person to write this playbook!

Hey everyone,
Oh my gosh? What is even going on right now? Jay and I have been in total amazement at how fast this campaign has been going along since we launched. We funded in less than 4 hours, which is the fastest by far out of the 5 combined kickstarters we've ran. 
And after we funded, we just kept going, and we've already unlocked EIGHT stretch goals at about 48 hours in! I'm so excited to be able to have the work of Luke, Caro, Kales, Abe, and Eric in our book! It's going to be incredible! The next stretch goal is Atlas's Warlock playbook, which is amazing, so let's keep it up!

campaign.story:
The last of humanity are fleeing across space, pursued by the implacable inhuman adversary that destroyed their civilisation. They're outnumbered and outgunned. Supplies are running low. The actions of a brave few could be all that stands between humanity and extinction.
Welcome to the Last Fleet.
Last Fleet is a tabletop roleplaying game where you play brave pilots, officers, engineers, politicians and journalists struggling to hold the human race - and themselves - together under unbelievable pressure. The game focuses on action, intrigue and drama in this high-stakes situation. You'll fight space battles, search for enemy infiltrators, tackle supply shortages and navigate faction politics. You'll strive against your own self-doubt and sometimes crack under the stress.
The game provides support to create your own evocative setting, or you can play out of the box as the survivors of the Interplanetary Commonwealth. This fractious alliance of planets was wiped out by the Corax - an extradimensional fungus network that dwells in the tenebrium, the same medium that FTL ships travel through. The Corax attack through spatial rifts, launching spore ships to harry the fleet. Victims are paralysed and have their genetic and neural patterns harvested: everything you know, the Corax now know. And worse, your former friends may see you again, reincarnated as a Corax avatar. 
Mockup of what the book will look like

Join the fleet today
The playbooks each represent a particular personality, approach or set of issues you want to explore. There are twelve:
 Aries, a hot-headed character who rushes in where angels fear to tread, and is unafraid to speak their mind.
 Taurus, a tough, selfless and principled character who does what’s needed no matter how much punishment is thrown at them.
 Gemini, a charismatic communicator who pursues their own agenda that might not be completely in line with the fleet’s interests.
 Cancer, an experienced leader who cares deeply for their comrades, but may be a little too willing to overlook their problems.
 Leo, a magnetic individual who people want to follow. Where will they lead them?
 Virgo, a serious professional who prides themselves on being the best, but may put themselves under too much pressure at time.
 Libra, a skilled diplomat and negotiator who may be looked to for leadership.
 Scorpio, a secretive manipulator whose motives are in doubt – including by themselves.
 Sagittarius, a relentlessly curious person who might be an explorer, engineer or spy, or perhaps all three.
 Capricorn, an uncompromising tactician who is willing to take risks to defeat the enemy. Will they take things too far?
 Aquarius, a perceptive investigator who does not shrink from confronting the truth, no matter how painful it might be.
 Pisces, an otherworldly person with strange abilities that allow them to see things others do not.
In addition to your playbook, you can choose a role within the fleet. You can play a military officer, pilot or marine, engineer or scientist, journalist or civilian leader. Each comes with its own special move.
PBTA
Last Fleet is based on the excellent Powered by the Apocalypse framework pioneered by Apocalypse World. In this case, that means it uses a simple 2d6 based system, with  prompts for interesting, dramatic outcomes from every roll; characters are organised into playbooks that provide everything you need on a single piece of paper; and GM advice is codified into clear principles that tell you not just how the mechanics work but how to get the best from the game.
Under Pressure
The game's mechanics push forward the central theme of pressure: pressure on your characters, pressure on the fleet, pressure on humanity. You can win almost any conflict if you're willing to pay the consequences, by racking up more pressure on your character that ultimately pushes them to Breaking Point. That's when your character goes off the rails, lashing out at their friends or hurling themselves into certain doom.
The only way to keep the pressure under control is by indulging your vices and risking losing control, or by building relationships that matter with other characters. Neither route is risk-free. When you're not putting your life on the line, you're putting your heart on the line.
Testimonials
"I had the good fortune to get in on a playtest of Last Fleet, and Joshua has delivered a satisfying and crunchy deep dive into the action, emotion, and escalating paranoia that make up the life of a Rag-Tag (space) Fugitive on the run from a mysterious, implacable, existential alien threat. I'm very much looking forward to having it on my tables to put into the eager hands of prospective CAGs, politicians, and shady operators."
- Jim Crocker, jimlikesgames.com
"From the very first session of Last Fleet, our group felt hunted! The tension that arises from just the premise of the game alone--humanity fleeing an implacable enemy--really fueled not just every action scene, but, especially, the interpersonal scenes as our characters reached out, broke down, let loose, and tried to maintain their humanity at the edge of annihilation."
-Zach Bain, playtester
"The beauty of Last Fleet is that you're going to want to put your characters under pressure -- the roleplaying that spins out is just so juicy. It's extremely clever, extremely fun design."
-Nick Bate, playtester
"Black Armada is part of a new generation of PbtA designers who are tackling new concepts in new genres with new ideas. Last Fleet is aimed at replicating some of my favorite fiction, and I'm excited to see Josh exploring concepts of authority, tension, and political pressure through that lens. I can't wait to see the finished game!"
-Mark Diaz Truman, Magpie Games
Try the game
If you want to see more - and see how the draft game layout is going - you can grab a free download of the reference sheets and playbooks. The current draft of the full game is available to backers in the first update to this campaign.
Actual play
You can take a look at how the game plays by watching the playtest recording below. The video kicks off with world building, character creation and relationship generation, but you can skip ahead if you'd like to see the mechanics in action. 
Kickstarter Budget
I'm raising money to cover print costs, art and layout. If I raise enough, there's stretch goals for extra art and setting material, but if I exactly meet my funding goal then the breakdown would look like this:   
About a 40% goes to art and layout, 30% to printing. The rest is editing, Kickstarter's fees, and a small amount of money for me, and contingency funds.
I will be printing extra books for post-Kickstarter sales, and that is included in the print costs. This means that, while my up-front pay is pretty low, I can expect fair compensation over the relatively short term if the campaign funds.
The 10% contingency is standard for Black Armada's crowdfunding campaigns. Stuff happens, estimates can be wrong, and prices are pretty volatile. Having a contingency fund has always proved a good choice in the past.
Fulfilment and Shipping
I plan to fulfil digital rewards through Drivethru, so backers will have access to the files in their Drivethru library.
I expect the game will be an A5 book around 200-250 pages in length. I plan to print the books with Biddles Books, who have provided books of exceptional quality for our previous projects Flotsam and Bite Marks.
Physical rewards will be shipped with Kixto, who have proved reliable warehousing partners on our previous projects. Shipping costs will be charged after the campaign has closed, so as to ensure that we neither over-charge nor under-charge you. Based on past experience, a single book will cost around £5 to ship within the UK, £8 (€10) within the EU, or £10 ($14) elsewhere.
The project team  
Josh Fox is the award-winning designer of Flotsam: Adrift Amongst the Stars, and (with Becky Annison) Lovecraftesque. He runs Black Armada Games with Becky Annison. Josh blogs about games and game design at Black Armada, writes smaller RPGs on Patreon and tweets as @armadajosh. 
Vincentius Matthew is a full-time freelance Concept Artist, digital sculptor, and Illustrator for games, animation, and film. He has worked with dozens of indie game makers, story writers, music composers, and some AAA video games such as Street Fighter V and Marvel Vs Capcom Infinite when he was working with Streamline Studios.
Anna Molla is an illustrator and designer from Berlin. She studied and lived in London for 4 years. She has contributed covers and page illustrations to RPGs such as Hypertellurians and The Solemn Scriptures of the Battle Nuns of the Mercyful Sepulcher. Anna is also involved in Matt Kay's Nordsaga. Additionally she sometimes does book illustrations and happily takes commissions from people in the RPG community as well. In her private time Anna is an avid scribbler of fanart and is currently writing her own D&D 5e campaign. You can find her online at Twitter (@An_Ka_Mo) and hopefully soon also on Instagram (@an__ka__mo).   
Elizabeth Lovegrove is an academic by day, roleplayer and knitter by night. She is the award winning writer of storygame Rise and Fall, part of Pelgrane Press's Seven Wonders anthology, and she has previously done layout work for Becky Annison's Bite Marks, published by Black Armada. You can find her on Twitter as @ejlovegrove.  
Mo Holkar is a UK game designer who is a partner in Freeform Games LLP and who has written for projects such as Lovecraftesque, Cthulhu Dark, and Flotsam. He also copyedits, including recently working on Bite Marks and Amazing Tales. In his spare time he writes larps, some of which can be found at his website holkar.net
Stretch goals
I have a series of stretch goals planned, which will be revealed as we move through the campaign. You can expect additional settings and scenarios from exciting game designers - and at each new stretch goal I'll add more and better art. Watch this space!
MORE SHIPS! MORE FACTIONS! (£19,000)
If we make it to £19,000, I'll commission a collection of indie authors to write a smorgasbord of ships and factions to expand the Last Fleet setting.
ICE CREAM! (funded!)
FUNDED! We made it to £17,500, so I'm taking my family out for ice cream!
(Seriously.)
Misha Bushyager is a longtime gamer and designer working on making sure the next generation of geeks sees themselves represented. She's a panelist, writer, editor, proofreader, and sensitivity editor for tabletop RPGs and larps. She's one of the founders of New Agenda Publishing and a curator for More Seats at the Table. She worked on Orun, #Feminism, Fate of Cthulhu, Lovecraftesque, Dead Scare, Misspent Youth:Sell Out With Me, Masks:Unbound, and the as yet unpublished larp Nightingales. You can find her on Twitter as @bggameworks and her website http://blackgirlgameworks.com.
FUNDED! We've made it to £16,000, so we're going to fund out: What happens when you escape your worst nightmare only for those to whom you fled to try and send you back? A group of Corax hosts who broke their programming and deserted are now prisoners of the fleet. What happens to them now?
Joanna Piancastelli is a tabletop RPG designer and larpwright. Her RPG Before the Storm was part of the IGDN Game of the Year Seven Wonders Anthology, and her Golden Cobra winning larp Unheroes has been played around the world.
FUNDED! Humanity has always consisted of those who lead and those who follow - which are you? We have reached £13,000 so Joanna Piancastelli will write Rank and Duty. An optional module that’s especially suited to games with a strong military focus, Rank and Duty brings more structure to the Last Fleet’s chain of command and helps you create play by making and breaking the rules.
Gav Thorpe has been a games designer and author for over twenty years, mostly in the Warhammer universes, and has worked on numerous tabletop and video games as designer, writer and world creation consultant. He is a New York Times bestselling author, and won the 2017 David Gemmell Legend Award for his novel Warbeast. 
FUNDED! We have reached £10,000 (about $13,000), so Gav will be writing a setting pack that takes the players to a fantastical realm of teleporting cities, crossing multiverses to escape the growing power of Death itself. Players must gain the goodwill of the gods through endeavour, sacrifice and prayer to stay ahead of doom.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is the third Kickstarter campaign we've run. We've delivered every product in full, and we're getting better at it - our last campaign was fulfilled 2 months early.

I'm a qualified project manager and I always prepare carefully for delivery of a new product. We have a detailed timeline and budget that reflects our best estimate of what's needed to make the project happen.

Every project comes with its own challenges. Key people get sick, prices change - with the best preparation in the world you can't be certain what will happen during delivery. That's why we always include a sizeable contingency allowance in our timelines and budgets.

When things go wrong, we will keep you updated regularly. We never go silent, and we always make sure if there's a risk to our planned delivery date, you're informed as early as possible.

Like our last two projects, this one is special because it takes place ahead of a possible UK exit from the EU. At this time it appears that the UK will officially leave the EU on 31st January, but will not have completed the transition period out of the EU before the end of 2020. We will therefore work very hard to (a) get the books printed before then, to avoid any risk of price changes, and (b) get the books shipped before then, to avoid any risk of delay at the ports. If we fail to achieve this, it will likely have an effect on how profitable the project is, and might delay receipt of the rewards, but it is very unlikely that it will torpedo the project.

Finally, we're supporters of Kickstarter United's efforts at unionising. The most recent news is that Kickstarter are talking to KSRU and we're hopeful this will lead to further good news in the near future. Nonetheless, should KSRU call for a boycott, we intend to pull our campaign from Kickstarter. If this happens, we'll aim to take the project forward in some way, at a later date.

Welcome, adventurers!
Here to Slay is a 2-6 player turn-based role-playing competitive strategic fantasy card game.
In this game, you’ll assemble a full party of heroes to slay dangerous monsters while working to avoid the sabotage of your foes. The game also includes items you can equip to your heroes, 1V1 challenge cards, and roll modifiers to tip the odds in your favor.
The first player to slay three monsters or assemble a full party wins the game!
As part of this project, we created exclusive and collectible items that you won't get anywhere else as a thank you for supporting us on Kickstarter. These items will not be available online or in retail stores at a later date.
PLAY

In Here to Slay, you'll start with a Party Leader and work to assemble a team of Heroes to take on savage Monsters. The first person to successfully slay three monsters, or build a full party with six classes, wins the game!
Every player gets to choose a party leader character to represent them throughout the game. Each party leader card has a class and a skill that gives you an edge over your opponents. Whether you enjoy fighters, bards, wizards, or thieves, you'll find a party leader that's right for your play style - but choose wisely, because you only get one party leader for the whole game!
Your heroes are brave adventurers, ready to attack monsters and go head to head with your foes! The game includes over 40 unique heroes. Each hero card has a class and an effect, and each hero’s effect has a roll requirement. In order to use a hero’s effect, you must roll two dice and score equal to or higher than that effect’s roll requirement. 
Everyone wants to be a hero, but are you brave enough to face off against these monsters? If you successfully slay three monsters, you win the game, but attacking a monster may come at a price! In order to slay that monster, you must roll two dice and score equal to or higher than that monster’s roll requirement. 
Be warned: Each monster has a roll range in which they’ll fight back, and if you score within that range, your party might be in grave danger...
Item cards are enchanted weapons and objects that can be equipped to your heroes to bestow them with special advantages and skills. Most items give beneficial effects and are meant to be equipped to heroes in your own party, but a handful of items, called cursed items, can be equipped to enemy heroes to give them disadvantages. 
What would this world be without a little magic and mayhem? Magic cards are powerful spells with a one-time effect. Some magic cards can give you great advantages, while others are designed to set your opponents back.
Don't like what your opponent just played? Throw down a challenge! Challenge cards can be played instantly to try to stop another player from playing a hero, item, or magic card. Playing a challenge card initiates a 1V1 challenge in which you and another player both have to roll the dice. If they win the challenge, they still get to play their card, but if you win the challenge, you get to send their card directly to the discard pile!
Only fools rely solely on luck. In this game, you can keep a modifier card up your sleeve (or, well, in your hand) to make sure the odds always tip in your favor. Modifier cards add or subtract from the final total of any dice roll. Whether you need to recover from a low roll or sabotage the high roll of an opponent, modifier cards can be a handy tool when luck doesn't seem to be on your side.

We use BackerKit to handle all add-ons. Two weeks after the campaign ends, we send out a BackerKit survey, and you can select add-ons (and enter your shipping information). US backers can purchase add-ons with no additional shipping charges, and backers anywhere else in the world will be charged just a flat $5 (for any number of items you want).
Because Here to Slay has a strong role-playing element, we wanted to include a way for you to bring your own character to the table. So as part of this project, we launched a party leader customizer that you can use to instantly create your own character using artwork that we’ve provided, or even upload your own.
You can also see characters that other members of the community have built - and the best part is, any custom party leader card that you create is fully playable in the game!
This project is promoted by Jellop, the ad tech power behind some of the best Kickstarter launches with 1,400+ successful Kickstarter projects and over $500M raised in total. They've been an amazing partner on this campaign and helped us grow our community! 
When our team first started working on Unstable Unicorns three years ago, we weren't really sure what to expect. We were huge fans of games, and some of us had even dabbled in designing games before, but we had never undertaken a large-scale project and seen it through to completion. The response was more than we could've ever expected, and it forever changed our work and our lives.
For the past few years, our team’s mission has been to design highly interactive games that are worth playing over and over. We want our games to bring people together, to help players express themselves, and ultimately to make the world a better place. We learn so much from every project, and each piece of feedback we get helps shape the future of what we create. 
The response we received on Here to Slay is nothing short of extraordinary. Your support means everything to us. We hope you enjoy what we create, and we will continue striving to delight you every single day.

campaign.story:
The city is dead. The grown-ups are gone. And the rain never, ever stops.
Libreté is a tabletop role-playing game that invites you to assume the lives of children trying to survive in a world without adults. To survive in The City you'll need to come together to form a community with other refugee children, overcome the gangs that seek to take what is yours and avoid being devoured by the Sirens of the Storm that lurk in every drop and puddle.
Finding your way home is an absurd fantasy—in The City everything is a struggle. Whether you're a newcomer, the head of a powerful faction or an established outcast, you'll quickly learn that nobody is coming to save you and that sometimes the only way to survive immediate danger is to embrace long-lasting trauma. How you cope with this stress, and how it affects your future decisions, determines the success of your isolated group.
The System
Libreté uses a modified Powered By The Apocalypse system with several new mechanics added, namely Bile: a measure of the characters' susceptibility to the dark instincts that inhabit us all. Bile is the same violence that drives a child to pick up a rock in a schoolyard fight, used to power through the fear that would otherwise paralyze them in the face of horrible death.
Is your child a pacifist or a coward? A warrior or a sociopath? Is this minor squabble going to better prepare you for the horrors to come or drive a knife through the tenuous fabric of your found community? Will you show mercy when given the chance? Will they?
At its heart the system is designed to encourage roleplaying while minimizing unnecessary mechanical tests. Class archetypes help you quickly create and flesh out a character and the flow of the game means that each skill check—whether successful or not—introduces new facets of the story.
Libreté has a simple and intuitive system for creating and developing your own sanctuary through emergent play. Together with your fellow players you'll design an enclave with multiple leaders, factions and problems—both immediate and eventual. For those who prefer to jump right into the game, the free Quick Start Guide features an introductory adventure designed to introduce players to the system and world of Libreté. 
The Book
Originally released to a French audience in 2016, this Kickstarter marks the first English translation of Vivien Féasson's Libreté. While the original French version was lauded for its setting and system, we've decided to bring on Ennie-award winning editors Fiona Geist and Jarrett Crader (MOTHERSHIP, Ultraviolet Grasslands, Fever Swamp, Silent Titans) to give the entire book a thorough re-working to impart clarity and ease-of-use. The layout is being redesigned from the ground up by Dai Shugars (The Demon Collective, Vol. 1, Magical Industrial Revolution) and will be presented as an a5 softcover digitally printed by Mixam with interior art by Mathieu Chevalier and cover/interior art by GMDK veteran Lauren Bryce (The Demon Collective, Vol. 1).
The main book and its supplements are already written and translated—an artless, raw-text document of the game will be sent to every backer as soon as the funding period concludes. Your money is going towards making this the best book it can be, a model of indie RPG design and usability. Physical book fulfillment will be handled by Exalted Funeral, and PDFs distributed by itch.io.
Like all GMDK books, PDFs will be layered, bookmarked, and optimized to full PDF/UA standards for the utmost in accessibility. It is our strong belief that RPGs are for everyone, and we make sure to put in the work so our readers don't have to. 
Fleur Du Mall
Fleur Du Mall is the first supplement for Libreté, and is designed to be an all-in-one adventure setup and location. Taking place in a reclaimed shopping mall, players will try to navigate the tenuous power balance between several factions: the iron-fisted  Glass Watch, the lawless Centrals, and the Boilers who crawl through the maintenance tunnels. If any one group gets too powerful, the stronghold might fall--leaving everyone to the mercy of the Sirains. 
In the City, dangerous monsters lurk in every pool and puddle.
Fleur Du Mall is already written, translated and edited. It's being provided here as a kind of add-on, without the trouble of managing pledges in Backerkit. If you want the full Libreté experience, consider backing at the PDF Deluxe or Print Deluxe level. Physical copies of Fleur Du Mall will be a5 softcovers printed via Mixam, identical in quality to our last book, The Demon Collective, Vol. 1.
Here's what some reviewers (translated from French) have said about Libreté: 
"Libreté wasn’t created for players looking into roleplaying games for fun and only for fun. With its radical and resolutely mature bias, the game wishes to provoke strong emotions and thinking around the table, and will ask a bit of rigor and discipline from all involved participants in order to lead them to the proper result. This clearly changes from classic RPGs and can sometimes be a bit complex to set up, since it requires changing old habits and even thinking about what is considered as “normal” within our hobby. Nonetheless, for all those who are ready to take the required step, the final impression will clearly match the investment." ⁠—Vincent L., SciFi Universe
"Many (too many) RPGs are beautiful gems only meant to be read (and then kept inside a library), while Libreté is the opposite of that, because it was created to be played and even to be felt. It is therefore the perfect example of the great evolution RPGs have experienced since Dungeons & Dragons. This is the kind of games that I write myself to create original experiences for friends more inclined towards blockbusters. A small book where every page and every word is important for the game, and even takes us far beyond, to something like an inner adventure that resonates within each one of us, each time in a different way." —Olivier T., UnificationFrance
As well as players in Vivien's annual GauntletCon games:
"Libreté is truly a special game! I am so impressed with [Viviens'] design, it's so elegant and evocative." — @temporalhiccup
"This game really opened my eyes to how changes in mechanics can radically drive game play." —@TaintedDingo
"English speaking roleplaying people, here is the very best of French RPG scene coming to you, in English." —@LamSon82225689
And here are some videos of those games, so you can see just what sort of stories you can tell with Libreté. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4k9ekbb_ak0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cJqhnS_-vr8&t=4614s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TSSo3EkkpAE&t=2s
 To avoid getting mired in post-production, we're keeping stretch goals simple and focused; we want to get this book to backers with a minimum of delays and potential problems, so we've decided to eschew fancy book ribbons or hand-outs in favor of what we know we can deliver on-time. 
$10,000: TWO New Supplemental Rulesets: "Injuries, Sickness, and Care" and "Creating NPCs"
Complementing the base rules found in the game, "Injuries, Sickness, and Care" provides more intricate systems for coping with the ravages of violence and disease. In a world without ready access to antibiotics, where a trip to the drugstore is an armed operation, infection can kill as quick as a knife. In addition to rules for diseases such as gangrene and tetanus, this supplement gives info about treating wounds and nutritional deficiencies for a grittier, more resource-management style of play.
As well, we'll include detailed rules for quickly designing other children to populate the world of Libreté. When you need a child on the fly--whether an up-and-coming gang boss, a new arrival to the fortress, or a mysterious loner who knows more than they let on--roll a few times on our tables to generate a unique character.
$12,500: THREE Advanced Archetypes: The Adult, The Addict, and The Sirain
These Archetypes are meant for advanced players, as they include mechanics that the base Archetypes don't.
As The Adult, you're the only grown-up in a city of children; naturally distrusted, but bearing the weight of an entire community on your shoulders. You have a wisdom and strength that they don't, but you'll feel every loss as if it were your own.
Meanwhile, The Addict knows just how terrible the city can be when you've got nobody to rely on but yourself. A little chemical assistance goes a long way in easing the nightmares, and you can stop anytime you want to. You just don't want to.
And then there's The Sirain: born of the storm, you find yourself at the gates of Libreté with no family, no purpose, and no memories--just a desire to find a place where you belong, and a gnawing hunger for flesh that you're desperately trying to conceal.
$15,000: More Art!
At this level, we'll be able to pay Lauren to provide more interior illustrations for both the main book and Fleur Du Mall. We'll also be able to do a larger print run, which means there will be books available after the Kickstarter for anyone who missed out. 
We are GMDK, a tabletop publishing company dedicated to producing and promoting the work of LGBT+ and other marginalized creators in the gaming community. This is our second Kickstarter, after The Demon Collective, Vol. 1 , which raised nearly 700% of its funding goal. With Libreté, we aim to show that the same principles that made The Demon Collective so successful—great art, tight editing and intuitive design—can be applied to all types of games.

Risks and challenges
Our first attempt at this was ambitious; we've scaled things back considerably for the re-release. The new Libreté will be svelte and compact, but we're confident we'll be able to deliver just as much of an incredible gaming experience with it. 

Aside from the form factor, several steps have been taken to ensure the production of Libreté goes smoothly. The book itself is written, translated, and edited; all it needs now is art and layout. We've gotten in touch with the printing company, and arranged for an established distributor to make sure your books get to you on time.

campaign.story:
For the Dungeon! is a comedy role-playing game where you get to play as the hapless minions instead of the heroes. Experience the rush of unquestioning loyalty to a darker power and charging into danger with reckless abandon! Raid villages, scout ancient ruins for artifacts, and protect the dungeon from homicidal adventurers.
Instead of a well established world, the game uses principles taken from Powered by the Apocalypse style games and improv comedy to create the setting. For the Dungeon! relies heavily on player created prompts that are interpreted by the Game Master to reveal the details of the world.
The game is designed to be fast-paced, with a focus on creating memorable moments. Because the game is light and has a greater focus on the story, anybody can pick up and play with minimal effort. The fun is created more through the unexpected scenarios the players get themselves into than by studying rules.
So how do you play? Characters are represented by a set of short descriptions called traits. They cover a character's skills, equipment, and motivations. Traits provide an easy way to know both who your character is and what they're good at.
Something inherent to being a minion is their penchant for chaos. Critical failures are a core part of what makes the game unique and fun. Whenever the characters critically fail the player provides a prompt that the Game Master uses as inspiration for whatever hilariously unexpected misfortune befalls them.
With failure comes experience. When a minion rolls a critical failure they write down what they learned from the experience instead of tracking experience points. These experiences can be used just like traits, but only as long as you continue to succeed.
In addition to playing as a minion, all players get to influence what is going on in the dungeon. During downtime, players choose from a handful of dungeon actions that alter the world to naturally create interesting story hooks to pursue.
There's a lot more that goes into making the game what it is. Feel free to download the Quick Start to get a better idea of the rules of For the Dungeon!
There are two ways to get your hands on a copy of For the Dungeon! The digital copy is a PDF and a great option for anyone looking to save some money. The physical copy is a paperback book with original art from our wonderful artist Jared. If you want to see more of his work feel free check him out on Instagram. We ship to most of the world, if your country isn't currently listed reach out either by message or comment and I'll be sure to add it. Here's what you're getting inside the book:
About 70 pages full of original full-color art
A guide to creating characters and selecting traits
A List of abilities that define minion playstyles
Helpful tips for using prompts to create the world
Advice to help GM's run the game
The game also includes a guide to creating alternate settings other than fantasy. Simple rules for altering and creating new abilities, items, and downtime actions allow Game Masters to run any kind of game they want with the system!
We now have add-ons! To receive any of the following just add the listed amount to your pledge total. We will have options for marking add-ons during the end of campaign surveys, but you can always send us a message to make sure we know which add-on you wanted or that the amount pledged is correct. There are currently two available add-ons.
The Deck of Many Prompts  ($14 U.S. / $24 Other Countries) - This deck is for those who want to add a bit of randomness to the game without the pressure of thinking up prompts on the spot. Whenever the situation calls for you to establish details simply draw a card and roll a die. The GM will then work the result into the fiction. Note: the image shown is just a placeholder and not the final product.
Map of Discovery ($16 U.S.) - This is a 11"x17" foldable dry-erase map featuring thematic imagery, that players get to explore and discover. It is also a great way to track the consequences of dungeon actions. Whenever the group angers a village or causes mayhem the consequences can be recorded for future use. As a bonus, the back of the map also features a grid that can be used with other role-playing games. Note: we are working on a way to make shipping this to international backers achievable.

campaign.story:
Infinity's Edge is a fantasy role-playing game based on the LitRPG genre of fiction. What does that mean? It means that players take on the role of fantasy heroes that are avatars in a virtual reality massively-multiplayer role-playing game. Their characters are aware that they are characters, and they have advantages that normal RPG characters don't have. For instance, if they die in battle, they can respawn at their most recent bind point. Death is no longer the end! It's become a tactical option. But there's always a price, and in Infinity's Edge death means a loss of XP and having to go find your body to get most of your equipment back. 
It also means that the NPCs in your fantasy game just became a completely new level of meta! They can discuss levels and classes with your characters, tell them where to find trainers, help them locate the best areas for their level and tell them what kind of loot different creatures drop. Higher level NPCs can tell characters about the abilities that they gain when they increase in level, and they can offer quests to anyone high enough level to qualify for them. Parties, guilds, and factions have mechanical effects including long-distance communication with one another through raid channels. 
One of the most significant aspects of this kind of game is that all the chatter around the table about game mechanics just went from out-of-character to in-character. Your characters can benefit from modern world knowledge and use as much regular slang or pop culture references as they want without breaking character (although NPCs may become a little tired of not understanding what they're talking about!). Characters will be offered quests, allowing them to choose their path knowing full well its difficulty and reward. And perhaps most importantly, from the time of character creation, they can take part in events that will shape the (virtual) world they inhabit!
An adventurer faces a scout from the orc legion on the steps of Holdfast, the dwarven stronghold!
Infinity's Edge uses a unique system designed from the ground up to work with conventional gaming dice but to emulate the mechanics in a modern MMO. At its core, the game works on a percentile system, with a fixed difficulty, or Threshold, for any given task. Characters have seven Attributes and gain Skills, both of which affect a character's chance for success on any given task that uses that particular combination. The default Threshold for success on any given roll is 60, meaning that a character will succeed on that roll if they get a 60 or less on a d100 roll. The higher a character's Attributes and Skills, the higher the Threshold goes, making it easier to succeed on the roll. 
The most important aspects of a character in Infinity's Edge are the three Meters: Health, Stamina, and Mana. Health is used to measure how much damage a character has taken, Stamina is spent to take actions, and Mana is used to fuel magic or supernatural effects.
One of the aspects of the game designed to emulate an MMO is the process of Skill acquisition. In Infinity's Edge, characters gain Skills through use. The first time a character attempts and successfully executes a Skill, they gain that Skill at rank 1. After that, they increase in rank through using it successfully. Five successful uses achieves rank 2, then ten successful uses grants rank 3, and so on. For those who prefer less bookkeeping in their games, we included a couple of alternative Skill progression methods suggested by our playtesters so you can customize to suit your preferences! One is based on overcoming challenges (such as battles), while the other is a straight experience point expenditure system. 
Characters in Infinity's Edge begin at level 1 and gain levels regularly through experience up to a maximum of level 50. At levels 1-9, the characters are Novices, during which time they develop their Attributes and Skills, and determine what their preferred playstyle is. At level 10, a character chooses their first class. Basic Classes, including the core concepts of Warrior, Rogue, Priest, and Wizard, are available to all characters, and there are six Hybrid Classes that mix two Basic Classes together. A combination of Priest and Warrior is a Paladin, for example, while a combination of Rogue and Wizard is called a Shadowmage. And there are Specialist Classes as well, which can be unlocked via play or by finding a trainer.
When a character chooses their first class, they choose three of six powerful, thematic abilities that establish the class's theme. A priest can focus on healing or buffs, for example. Every five levels after 10, a character may choose one additional ability, completing all of the class's default options by level 25 unless substitute abilities are offered through quest unlocks. Then, at level 30, the character chooses their Advanced Class, and an entirely new level of play is unlocked! The core rules of Infinity's Edge focus on the first 30 levels, but Advanced Classes are already in playtest!
Finally, although the LitRPG genre as well as numerous anime series (which were a strong secondary source of inspiration) tend to have protagonists who cannot log out of the game, in Infinity's Edge that option is still on the table if you want it for your games. Have the real world impact the game world by incorporating interpersonal conflicts between gamers, corporate politics surrounding game releases, and anything else you can think of! It's all in there!
Playtest character Aragil (Base Class: Wizard) selects the perfect spell for those pesky bats.
Infinity's Edge is a full-color rulebook that is estimated at roughly 75-80 pages in length. Choosing to back this Kickstarter entitles you to either a digital copy of the game in the form of a PDF or a print-on-demand physical copy created via DriveThruRPG. If you're reading this, you probably already know how good their products are.
Infinity's Edge has already been written. It's currently undergoing edits as we speak, and a portion of the art is already finished, with more in development right now. The funds from the Kickstarter will enable us to finish up the rest of the art rather than having to do it over a long period of time and begin layout immediately upon receipt of the art. But, to reiterate, the longest and most arduous part of the process, the writing and playtesting, was completed before this campaign went live. No additional content will be added to the core rules as a result of this Kickstarter, ensuring that delays will be kept to an absolute minimum.

Character Gail, the brilliant prodigy, tames a draco-cat (and names her Athena) as her companion!

Shawn Carman is the lead writer for this game. Having discovered LitRPG during the summer of 2018, he has consumed a truly disturbing number of novels since that time, created a game to play with his friends, then ended up writing an entire rulebook about it and finding artists that could create it with him. Shawn is the former head writer for Legend of the Five Rings at Alderac Entertainment Group (for well over a decade, we might add) as well as the creative director and chief writer for Thunderscape, the flagship RPG of Kyoudai Games for the past six years.
Chris Camarata is an audiobook enthusiast and a fellow LitRPG junkie who got very excited when he heard what Shawn was working on. He has been an invaluable sounding board and system designer for Infinity's Edge, with a particular emphasis on the races and the settlement building rules.
Mike Brodu is the graphic design master for Kyoudai Games, and always the wisest man in the room when it comes down to how things look on the page. He knows exactly what kind of margins there have to be and exactly how big the logo can (and must!) be on the front. He's a dark wizard of pictures and we both love and fear him for his powerful magics.
Kim Wong Lim is the single most prolific artist working on the project and has single-handedly helped determine how this game was going to look. He is both a gentleman and a scholar whose artistic talents cannot be overstated. You can check out more of his amazing work right here!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Question: Can Kyoudai Games handle this Kickstarter?
This is not our first Kickstarter. We learned a lot from the first two, unfortunately most of it being what we shouldn't do. This Kickstarter has no shipped products (except maybe some add-ons that are already in hand and shippable), and limits our stretch goals to avoid over-promising. The book is written (and nothing will be added to the core book through this Kickstarter, which can cause delays), roughly half the art is already complete, and contracts are lined up for the rest as well as for layout. This project is as close to complete as we can make it with our currently available resources.

Question: What if the text / art / layout isn't finished?
The text is finished. The art is 50% complete and we have arrangements for the rest. We have someone lined up for layout, and if that falls through, we have someone else who can take on the project in the event of an emergency. There is a secondary and tertiary project manager in place with copies of all the assets who can take over if something happens to Shawn. Our failsafes have failsafes. 

Question: What about printing / shipping issues?
Our printing and shipping partners at DriveThruRPG operate worldwide and are well known for getting products into the hands of fans at extremely affordable rates and with minimal fuss. Our faith in them is boundless!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

The proof for the Shorefall Campaign arrived last night! I didn't get to look through it until today, but when I get home this evening I will be sending out the PDFs and POD links for all backers! I hope you enjoy that particular campaign as much as I did when we ran it a few times during playtest!
The release of the Shorefall Campaign will conclude the obligations of this Kickstarter. I have a few more things in mind that will be coming along, but they will tend to be smaller, PDF-only releases meant to give GMs more tools to build things. I may go with a few adventures, it just depends. And of course I love Specialist Classes. AND I am almost done (four chapters to go) with the novelization I have written of the original Shorefall Campaign playthrough. So that's weird. I'm sorry that this last product was so much later than originally intended, but let's be honest: this is not the same world we lived in when this Kickstarter was live. I am enormously grateful to all of you for your support and understanding.

Hey Infinites!
I just wanted to drop you a line and let you know that the final stretch goal of our campaign, the Shorefall Campaign, is in layout. Hopefully I will have a PDF to share with you within a couple of weeks, and then it will just be a matter of waiting to get it approved for printing. You guys have already seen the text, of course, so hopefully any errors or concerns were sent to me so I could take care of them in advance!

Hello, Infinites! I missed the May 2020 update. But I blame 2020, because what the hell. I didn't sign up for this stuff, man. 
Nevertheless, I share the Shorefall text with you guys already. I found some amazing art assets from 2 Minute Tabletop that work great for individual encounters, and... well, I've decided that my attempts to perfect my own maps is never, ever, ever going to work. I can't find any cartographers out there who are taking work on our reasonable budget, so I just have to accept that my work, while not exactly what you might call "good," is serviceable enough. campaign.story:
Charmed and Dangerous: The Sisters Grimm is a cooperative, adventure card game that gives 1-4 players the chance to take on the role of a classic fairy tale Princess, reimagined as a RPG style adventurer. You and your friends can choose to face a different Villainess and her amassed Forces of Evil each time you play.
Once the adventure begins, you and your fellow Princesses will explore bramble-thorn forests, sinister dungeons and labyrinthine castles in your quest to uncover and defeat the Villainess and save the realm!
PLAY

 The classic princesses of myth, legend and fairy tale have been reimagined as powerful and diverse RPG heroes.  Each Princess has different skills, facets and special abilities that makes her unique and changes the game each time you play. During the adventure, you can find rare artifacts, spells, magical attacks and even a dashing Charming to assist you on your adventure.  
Each Villainess can be paired with one of the “Forces of Evil” decks that come with a themed Lair. Each FoE deck is filled with monsters, traps and curses that you will have to defeat as you proceed through the game. 

PLAY

We believe in Charmed and Dangerous so much that the game has already been sent to the printers and is in production. Less waiting. More playing!
From its inception, Charmed and Dangerous has been about inclusion and representation. Our goal was not only to create a game with an all-Princess cast reimagined as classic, RPG style adventurers, but also to create a diverse family of heroines. It was critical to us that underrepresented people of the gaming community be able to see a reflection of themselves in the heroines of Charmed and Dangerous. Whether it is their race, heritage, sexual orientation or gender identity, our Princesses do not shy away from letting the world see exactly who they are and where they came from. And while we only launched with a small set of Princesses, please know that we have many more in the works and are dedicated to expanding the breadth of our representation.
- The Charmed and Dangerous Team

Shipping will be charged separately from the Kickstarter via our Pledge Manager, after the campaign ends. We expect to be closing the Pledge Manager in late June, early July.
Depending on where you live, the actual shipping cost will be somewhere between 8.00 USD and 12.00 USD, before accounting for VAT and Import Taxes.
Depending on the VAT rates in your country, you can expect to pay:
 Retail Edition: Between 28.00 and 35.80 USD
 Premium Edition: Between 38.00 and 47.70 USD
The above two price ranges INCLUDE THE PRICE OF THE GAME + S&H + VAT.

Hello, friends, Princesses, and Charmings and welcome to our May update. We hope you are all staying safe and well. We have a few updates for you today and an exciting announcement to show our thanks for your support and feedback during this Kickstarter and the subsequent launch. So, without further ado, let's get to the updates!
Fulfillment Updates

campaign.story:
First Kings is a pen&paper roleplaying game that features a pretty unique setting, based on a Dark Fantasy uchronia that casts its own particular lights and shadows on the history and the mythology that permeates the legend of the foundation of Rome. 
This new and highly immersive historical-fantasy RPG, with intense dark atmospheres, conceived by Matteo Sanfilippo, and designed & developed with Andrea Macchi and Max Castellani from Epic Party Games (previously on Kickstarter with Shattered Tower RPG), will throw you right in the middle of a raw, ancient Rome   ..not the rich and glorious Imperial Rome of the splendors that you are used to see in movies, videogames or history books, though, but a nebulous and more bare Rome, where the mist and the darkness beyond the walls frighten even the most courageous of men, where the very streets of the nascent citadel can become dangerous and deadly at nightfall, where the howls and the shrieking cries of the Horrids of the woods fill the nightmares of every Roman.  
(read more about the original setting down below, in the "An Old Dark World" chapter). 


The modern and innovative game mechanics consist mainly of a high narrative component, which emphasizes the interpretation as the protagonist of the whole gameplay.  
At the very same time it leans upon the solid foundations of an elaborate and very special D12System - the ZodiacusSystem -that unites narration, dice-pool, zodiac, numerology and lunar phases, in order to create a rule set and a character building system  unique in their kind. 
(read more about the system down below, in the "Game Mechanics" chapter). 
[First Kings will be produced in both English & Italian Language] 
go to the Italian language page
INDEX:
An Old Dark World (introduction to the setting)
Of Gods, Wolves & Men (introduction to the story background)
Game Mechanics (Character Creation, Scene & Tests, Zodiac Symbols, Rituals, Avernus)
Rewards
Stretch Goals
